urn:contentItem:5XJ8-NKG1-DYTH-G2BX-00000-00REPS. GARCA, TLAIB INTRODUCE BILL TO PROTECT CONSUMERS FROM MARKET MANIPULATION2019-11-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:21:30ZLexisNexisREPS. GARCA, TLAIB INTRODUCE BILL TO PROTECT CONSUMERS FROM MARKET MANIPULATIONStates News ServiceWASHINGTON

The following information was released by the office of Illinois Rep. Jesus Garcia:

Today Congressman Jess "Chuy" Garca (IL-04) and Congresswoman Rashida Tlaib (MI-13) introduced the Protecting Consumers from Market Manipulation Act, a bill to limit the revenue that large non-financial companies can derive from financial activity. The Protecting Consumers from Market Manipulation Act restricts big tech's involvement in banking, and guards against banks' ability to manipulate the price of commodities.

"As a community organizer and life-long advocate for working families, I have seen first-hand how the growth of monopolies, mega-corporations and big banks has exacerbated income inequality and threatened our nation's economic stability. Many families are still feeling the effects of the 2008 economic crash in Chicago's Little Village," Rep. Garca said.

"Whenever we allow the line between banking and commerce to blur, working-class families suffer. Big banks like Goldman Sachs, JP Morgan Chase, and Morgan Stanley have already been caught manipulating everything from electricity rates to oil and aluminum prices. Simultaneously, big tech companies like Facebook and Google are moving to the financial services sector where they currently evade existing banking regulations. Congress has a responsibility to protect working families and keep banking and commerce separate; that's why I am introducing the Protecting Consumers from Market Manipulation Act and the Keep Big Tech Out of Finance Act, which I introduced last month," Rep. Garca continued.

"Time and again we have seen that big banks and big tech companies cannot be trusted to put people before profit," Rep. Tlaib said. "Working-class families in my district are still struggling to recover from the 2008 recession caused by corporate greed and recklessness. By introducing the Market Manipulation Act, I hope to ensure that what progress we have been able to make is safeguarded from the threat of allowing an unchecked, unregulated blurring of lines between banking and commerce that has already resulted in examples of clear manipulation, discrimination, and privacy violations."

A fact sheet about the Protecting Consumers from Market Manipulation Act can be found here.

The bill's introduction comes one week after Google announced a new initiative to offer checking accounts to consumers and regulators opened an investigation into discrimination by Apple's new credit card. The Protecting Consumers from Market Manipulation Act is part of a package of bills strengthening the separation between banking and commerce, which Rep. Garca announced on the 20th anniversary of landmark financial deregulation.

urn:contentItem:5XJB-KH31-JC11-10VD-00000-00Reps. Garcia, Tlaib Introduce Bill to Protect Consumers From Market Manipulation2019-11-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:21:30ZLexisNexisReps. Garcia, Tlaib Introduce Bill to Protect Consumers From Market ManipulationTargeted News ServiceWASHINGTON

Rep. Jesus Chuy Garcia, D-Illinois, issued the following news release:

Today Congressman Jesus "Chuy" Garcia (IL-04) and Congresswoman Rashida Tlaib (MI-13) introduced the Protecting Consumers from Market Manipulation Act, a bill to limit the revenue that large non-financial companies can derive from financial activity. The Protecting Consumers from Market Manipulation Act restricts big tech's involvement in banking, and guards against banks' ability to manipulate the price of commodities.

"As a community organizer and life-long advocate for working families, I have seen first-hand how the growth of monopolies, mega-corporations and big banks has exacerbated income inequality and threatened our nation's economic stability. Many families are still feeling the effects of the 2008 economic crash in Chicago's Little Village," Rep. Garcia said.

"Whenever we allow the line between banking and commerce to blur, working-class families suffer. Big banks like Goldman Sachs, JP Morgan Chase, and Morgan Stanley have already been caught manipulating everything from electricity rates to oil and aluminum prices. Simultaneously, big tech companies like Facebook and Google are moving to the financial services sector where they currently evade existing banking regulations. Congress has a responsibility to protect working families and keep banking and commerce separate; that's why I am introducing the Protecting Consumers from Market Manipulation Act and the Keep Big Tech Out of Finance Act, which I introduced last month," Rep. Garcia continued.

"Time and again we have seen that big banks and big tech companies cannot be trusted to put people before profit," Rep. Tlaib said. "Working-class families in my district are still struggling to recover from the 2008 recession caused by corporate greed and recklessness. By introducing the Market Manipulation Act, I hope to ensure that what progress we have been able to make is safeguarded from the threat of allowing an unchecked, unregulated blurring of lines between banking and commerce that has already resulted in examples of clear manipulation, discrimination, and privacy violations."

A fact sheet about the Protecting Consumers from Market Manipulation Act can be found here (https://chuygarcia.house.gov/sites/chuygarcia.house.gov/files/Protecting%20Consumers%20Against%20Market%20Manipulation%20Act%20Fact%20Sheet.pdf).

The bill's introduction comes one week after Google announced a new initiative to offer checking accounts to consumers and regulators opened an investigation into discrimination by Apple's new credit card. The Protecting Consumers from Market Manipulation Act is part of a package of bills strengthening the separation between banking and commerce, which Rep. Garcia announced on the 20th anniversary of landmark financial deregulation.

Johnson, Mcadams Introduce Proposal to Protect Children From Dangerous App ContentTargeted News ServiceWASHINGTON

Rep. Mike Johnson, R-Louisiana, issued the following news release:

* * *

- Resolution calls on tech industry to self-regulate app market utilized by millions of minors

* * *

U.S. Representatives Mike Johnson (R-La.) and Ben McAdams (D-Utah) introduced a bipartisan resolution designed to empower parents to protect their children from dangerous and exploitative content on digital apps.

Specifically, the resolution calls on technology and app development companies to establish an industry-run app rating board to develop age-appropriate app ratings, user-friendly parental controls, digital wellness features and other tools to foster a safe, online environment for the millions of minors using apps daily.

"As parents of four children, Kelly and I have used movie, video game and music ratings to help decide what entertainment content is appropriate and safe for our family. Unfortunately, the tech industry does not hold digital apps to the same standard," said Johnson.

"For too long, apps have been allowed to serve as hubs for bullying, pornography and other types of content that jeopardize children's safety and well-being. It's time for Big Tech to step-up and do its part to make sure children are protected from dangerous and exploitative app content."

"Salt Lake County police arrested 30 online predators in four days last month alone, in a crackdown on cybercrimes. Parents need accurate and complete information about the apps available to their kids and user-friendly parental controls to protect their children," said McAdams.

"This resolution calls on tech companies to provide that. Nothing should get in the way of keeping our kids safe from online exploitation."

urn:contentItem:605S-2921-JC11-13DR-00000-00Rep. Smith: The Cancel Culture of Free Speech2020-06-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:21:31ZLexisNexisRep. Smith: The Cancel Culture of Free SpeechTargeted News ServiceWASHINGTON

Rep. Jason Smith, R-Missouri, issued the following Capitol Report column:

In recent weeks, big tech companies have intensified their attacks on conservatives' free speech. These massive corporations can do this because they have built considerable control over all of the information Americans view online. The vast majority of internet searches in the United States, over 88%, begin on Goggle's website. Millions of us wake up and check our social media platforms, like Twitter or Facebook, to see what happened while we were sleeping. One of the reasons these companies have been able to rise to their meteoric heights is because of protections extended through Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act. The section essentially states that these companies cannot be held responsible for the content of others on their platforms. It was intended to keep the internet free and open, but it is being abused by these companies to limit free speech and control what we do and don't see on the internet.

Earlier this week, it was reported that Google planned to ban The Federalist, a conservative publication, over readers' comments left on their website. Google said it would no longer run ads on their website. This decision shows not only the sheer power Google wields online, but also the raw hypocrisy that exists in Silicon Valley. Apparently, Google is not okay with websites like The Federalist and their conservative readers sharing their perspectives, but their left-leaning employees have no problem protecting free speech they agree with. Sadly, this selective enforcement is not limited to just Google. Twitter has, on several occasions, hid or flagged tweets made by President Trump for rhetoric they simply don't agree with. However, those regulating free speech at Twitter have made no effort to silence any other world leader on its platform, like Ayatollah Khomeini, the Supreme Leader of Iran. These tech companies are widely inconsistent about how and when they enforce their policies. They must be held accountable for consistently taken disproportionate action to silence conservative voices they disagree with.

In Missouri, we know that these massive companies cannot continue to violate our Constitutional rights. To ensure they don't, Senator Josh Hawley recently introduced the Limiting Section 230 Immunity to Good Samaritans Act. This bill prevents the Section 230 protections from being provided to online companies unless they clearly detail their content moderation policies and pledge to enforce them in good faith. Under this legislation, when Americans feel these companies are not living up to their end of the deal, they can sue for $5,000 and attorney's fees. Silencing free speech is illegal in the United States, and it is something the American people will never accept. Google, Twitter, Facebook, and others, must understand that they are not too big to be held accountable.

The past few weeks have shown just how powerful these massive tech companies have become. Yet, the threat towards the free speech of conservative voices is not only a fight playing out online but also in newsrooms at some of the largest and oldest publications in this country. After having published an op-ed written by Arkansas Senator Tom Cotton, The New York Times faced a firestorm of liberal criticism. The paper's own staff were not prepared to read a viewpoint with which they did not agree. So, rather than engage in debate on the ideas, they complained that the opinions expressed by Senator Cotton amounted to violence. Words are not violence, and the views expressed by Senator Cotton on the looting and rioting are held by many Americans. Yet after initially supporting the piece's publication, the publisher of the New York Times later bowed down before the mob and fired the Head of the Opinion desk who allowed the opinion piece to be published.

We are entering a dangerous time in America. We used to believe that the best medicine for bad free speech was more free speech. Yet today, it seems that the liberal mob wants to burn books and silence voices. The day our voices become silenced; is the day we stop being Americans.

Steve Scalise (R-LA) Is Interviewed About The Economy; Fed Chair Jay Powell To Release Prepared Testimony; Friends Leaving Netflix; Park Place Payments Raised More Than $1 Million In Seed Funding; Powell Watching Trade Developments, Federal Debt Ceiling, Brexit; Playing Sports Politics; Biden's Prison Plan2019-07-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:21:31ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA8:00 AM ESTMitch Roschelle, Lindsey Bell, Ed Lazear, Sam Ettus, Steve ScaliseNEWSFinancial071003cb.231Rep. Steve Scalise (R-LA) Is Interviewed About The Economy; Fed Chair Jay Powell To Release Prepared Testimony; Friends Leaving Netflix; Park Place Payments Raised More Than $1 Million In Seed Funding; Powell Watching Trade Developments, Federal Debt Ceiling, Brexit; Playing Sports Politics; Biden's Prison PlanMaria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Jackie DeAngelis, Dani Klupenger, Stuart Varney, Kristina Partsinevelos; Edward Lawrence, Gerri Willis

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Wednesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Wednesday, July 10th. Your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast. All eyes on Federal Reserve Chairman Jay Powell this morning. He is testifying this morning, hiss prepared remarks will come out of the embargo in 30 minutes.

We will bring you those remarks at 8:30 a.m. Eastern. They may very well move markets. Ahead of the testimony, futures are pointing to a lower opening for stock prices this morning. It's been pretty steady are the markets await Jay Powell. Futures indicating a decline of 56 points on the Dow, 6-1/2 points lower on the S&P and the NASDAQ down 15. This after a mixed day on Wall Street yesterday.

The Dow edged lower while the NASDAQ and the S&P 500 finished with modest gains. All three major indices less than one percent below their record highs. 43 points higher on the NASDAQ yesterday. Global markets this morning, little changed to lower, European indices are mostly lower, take a look but it's a fractional move. FT-100 down six, CAC quarante is up three and the DAX Index lower by 56.

In Asia overnight, mixed moves there as well. As you see, really just fractional. New U.S.-China trade talks on the table. Both sides holding a constructive phone call we're told. We've got the details on that call that took place yesterday. Netflix says farewell to Friends. The hit show has a new home for streaming. We'll tell you where. And then celebrating the women's World Cup victory. Fans already lining the streets of New York for a big parade.

All stories coming up this Wednesday morning and joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, PwC Partner, Mitch Roschelle and CFRA Investment Strategist, Lindsey Bell. Great to see everybody this morning.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA: Good to be here.

BARTIROMO: China called yesterday moving slowly but it's all about the Fed, isn't it?

MITCH ROSCHELLE, PARTNER, PWC CHARITABLE FOUNDATION: At least they're talking but in half an hour we're going to get advance remarks and that could be a nothingburger though because I think they're going to be carefully chosen words and we may not learn much more than wait and see.

BARTIROMO: In the morning note of J.P. Morgan this morning they basically write what you've been saying for weeks and that is, it's not about what the Fed is going to do, it's about questioning whether or not any cut in rates really going to move the needle on things.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Right. It doesn't actually have any stimulus or any meaningful impact to our economy or the global economy. It just might signal that the Fed's worried and that alone is bad news if they cut.

BELL: Absolutely. You usually need to see about a five percentage point cut to see any stimulus to the economy, Johnny Ellis said that and that's what we got in 2001 and 2007 and we don't even have that now.

ROSCHELLE: If there is a cut, it could almost be symbolic that the Fed is interested in keeping the growth going and they're willing to make a concession to see if that happens.

BARTIROMO: And I still question why we're talking about rate cuts when you got unemployment story that's at a 51-year low, and three percent still growth in the first quarter, but, of course, we are on the doorstep of second-quarter earnings and you're expecting a decline in S&P earnings.

BELL: Right. So the current consensus estimate is for a decline in 1.8 percent. I think it will come in better than that.

BARTIROMO: You do.

BELL: Or be slightly positive. Sales expectations are also very low for 3.7 percent positive growth and that's coming up five percent -- 5-1/2 percent the last two quarters and 9-1/2 percent the four quarters before that. So I think that's becoming a lot better and that will help the bottom line.

ROSCHELLE: And I've harped on this before, the strong dollar is going to weigh on those foreign sales for those S&P 500 who have sales abroad. So - -

BELL: Absolutely. 43 percent of the S&P 500 revenues come from overseas with eight percent of that coming from Asia. So --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: It's an important point because Europe has been really hard- pressed to generate any growth there and we don't know really what the number is in China.

BELL: Yes. You're starting to see a slowdown in Europe, that is being driven by the slowdown in China. Germany is a huge manufacturing economy obviously and they send machines for automobiles to China and China is just not buying them, so the ripple effect is starting to occur in the slowdown that we're having in China which is being impacted significantly by trade.

BARTIROMO: We're talking about all of this this morning. And joining the conversation, House Minority Whip, Steve Scalise is here. The host of "VARNEY & COMPANY" Stuart Varney weighs in as well. Don't miss a moment of it. And right now we're taking a look at our top story and that is Jay Powell on Capitol Hill. Investors are keeping a close eye on the Fed Chair's testimony before the House Financial Services Committee today.

And then, of course, Thursday, he'll speak with the Senate. His comments are embargoed for the next 25 minutes but we will have those comments at 8:30 a.m. Eastern. We will bring them to you because they may very well maybe market moving. Markets will be paying specific attention to see if Powell indicates signs that we will see a rate cut in the future whether it's July, September, we don't know.

Joining me right now is the former Chief Economic Adviser for George W. Bush, Ed Lazear is with me. Ed, it's great to see you. How are you?

ED LAZEAR, MORRIS ARNOLD COX SENIOR FELLOW, HOOVER INSTITUTION: Doing very well, thanks for having me, Maria.

BARTIROMO: And what are you expecting from Jay Powell today?

LAZEAR: Well, I think your earlier comments are probably right. I guess he'd be cautious. It's not that he doesn't know what he's planning to do. Obviously, they're -- you know, there are going to be some numbers that come out between now and decision time. But I think Powell is a guy who actually listens carefully to the other members of the committee. He is not someone who necessarily makes up his mind in advance and then tries to persuade everybody else.

So, I think the only uncertainty that there is between now and then is how other members feel about the state of the economy and I think he will be cautious because I think he is going to want to hear how those things play out.

BARTIROMO: So, let's talk about state of the economy because that's what we're debating. We just came off of a quarter that showed 3.1 percent growth, we've got unemployment at a 51-year low. How do you characterize things right now, the backdrop?

LAZEAR: Well, I think things look good. But the reason I'm slightly hesitant is because it does look like we are getting close to the top and the obvious indicator of that is actually the labor market, that's where I always look first. If you look at the labor market, we know there are a number of things going on. First of all, job creation is still good, if you look at the numbers, 171,000 over the past three months is still well above what we need to keep up with population growth.

But it is considerably down from where we were last year. So, it looks like we're getting closer to the peak. The employment rate is pretty much level. And the other thing that we look at is wage growth. Wage growth is kind of right on target right now. What you expect for wage growth when you're at the peak of an economy is that wages grow at the rate of inflation plus the rate of productivity which is right about in low threes, just about what we're seeing right now.

So, things look good but they look kind of like we're stable, we're at the top. The other thing I would say, Maria, is that if you look -- if you look at other indicators, the good news -- the best news actually is investment. So investment is still strong, I think we had six percent growth in the first quarter. That's very important. We're still above the three percent that we need to kind of keep pace with long-term growth rates, that's good.

The extent that there are negatives, it would be flattening in the housing market, flattening in industrial production. Again, those are indicators that we're getting close to the top.

BARTIROMO: Well, I mean, the Journal reported a couple of months ago that CapEx, it was up 20 percent and now it's only up three percent.

LAZEAR: Right.

BARTIROMO: So you're saying -- is that what you're talking about when you say investment?

LAZEAR: Yes. That's -- so -- right, exactly. So, if you -- now, when you say it was up, remember, the reason it's up is you're comparing it to the previous two years. If you look at the last couple of years of the Obama administration, I don't I mean to be political but it was during that period of time, we -- you know, capital expenditure was quite low, we didn't have good investment during that period.

BARTIROMO: That was because of the rules and the regulations I think.

LAZEAR: Well, I agree. You know, it wasn't like President Obama was the most pro-market president, although I'll tell you, you know, compared with what we're hearing right now, he looks like Margaret Thatcher. So, you know, I -- we do have some uncertainty going forward in terms of the politics of it. But, again, back to the numbers, if you just think about what we're seeing right now, the growth in investment is still very strong relative to where it's been.

So that's still OK. The best indicator, you know, as I've told you before, this is what I believe is the best indicator of future growth is the market. And if you look at the S&P 500, change in the S&P 500 over the past three or six months, it's indicating about two percent growth for the next four quarters. So, you know, two percent is not break-out growth but it's not recession either.

BARTIROMO: So. How contingent is this growth story on a deal with China? I mean, so we had talks resume yesterday. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer and Treasury Secretary Mnuchin spoke with their Chinese counterparts on the phone yesterday, both sides say that they're trying to get negotiations back on track, the U.S. is now allowing sales to go to Chinese telecom giant Huawei if there's no national security threat.

But, look, this has been slow-moving, we know that the Chinese reneged on all the important issues that the U.S. wanted in that deal. Do you think we'll see a deal and how contingent is U.S. growth on a deal?

LAZEAR: I do think we'll see a deal. But I also do not suffer delusions of grandeur on that either. I -- when you look at China and you ask how much does it mean to the United States? Obviously, it's important, China is a huge economy, second largest economy in the world. But if you ask how much do we export to China as a proportion of our GDP, it's less than one percent. So, suppose we would double that, that would be a, you know, that would be enormous.

Supposed we were to double that in the next year, what you're talking about is the equivalent of four months growth in GDP for the United States. So, it matters, that's not trivial but it's not -- it's not going to just transform our whole economy. So, I think when people look at these things and they say, oh my gosh, trade with China, you know, that's killing the economy. I don't buy that. I think the, you know, I'm not a fan of tariffs. I don't like the antitrade policies in the first place.

BARTIROMO: Right.

LAZEAR: But I don't think that that has had a tremendously negative effect on our economy.

BARTIROMO: Well, people have recognized the national security threat as it relates to China.

LAZEAR: Absolutely.

BARTIROMO: And for so many years, CEOs were just so interested in getting a foothold to sell to 1.4 billion people in China, they forgot to protect their own products. And now we recognize that the Chinese have stolen that intellectual property and are beginning to beat America at its own game. Look, we're going to continue following that but I got to ask about this White House summit. They're holding a social media summit tomorrow at the White House.

Big tech leaders not on the invite list, many who have -- will be there have faced intent censorship. Last month I spoke with the President about his plans for big technology. Listen to what he said. I found it interesting. I got to get your cake.

LAZEAR: OK. OK.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: How concerned are you that technology companies are censoring conservatives and they're going to do this right up to the 2020 election.

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES (via telephone): They make it very hard for people to join me on Twitter and they make it very much harder for me to get out the message, they make it -- it's incredible. Yes.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: So what are you going to do about it? What do -- I mean, these companies have an enormous amount of power if they could even stop the President of the free world.

TRUMP: Twitter is just terrible what they do, they don't let you get the word -- I've had so many people come to me, sir, I can't join you on Twitter. I see what' happening 100 percent.

BARTIROMO: So do you -- would you rather see competition or do you want to see legislation coming down to actually --

TRUMP: Well, you may need legislation in order to create competition.

BARTIROMO: It's what technology companies are doing, what they did to you, is that legal? Are they breaking the law, Mr. President?

TRUMP: Well, I don't know whether or not, but I tell you what, they should be sued.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: They should be sued. And then he said after that, we might sue them. We were talking about Google in particular. And he said, legislation will lead to competition. Ed, what do you think about this, regulation on the horizon for big tech?

LAZEAR: Well, I don't know if it's on the horizon. I always worry about regulation, you know, I can think back a decade or even 15 years ago when we were worried about Microsoft taking over the world, you know, there is always a technology that we're worried about taking over the information space. And what we've seen in that field, the good thing about that field is that because it is so dynamic, you do see new things coming in all the time. So competition tends to be pretty strong even on its own --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

LAZEAR: -- in the tech area. And, you know, there -- look, there's plenty of competition on the airwaves, you know, Fox does -- has one take on things and if you watch CNN, you're going to get a completely different take on it. So, probably shouldn't have said that on your -- on your network but --

BARTIROMO: No, no. You're right because CNN has a definite different take for sure. We're covering the issues that we think are important to the American people. So I want to end where it began and that is the Federal Reserve. Ed, real quick. If the Fed cut rates this year, do they look less independent because of the President's prodding and taunting of Jay Powell?

LAZEAR: You know, obviously, President Trump is a bit more public in his criticism than other presidents have been this the past. This is not a new phenomenon. If you ask Alan Greenspan, you know, whether he suffered criticism, pressure from other presidents --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Yes. Maybe behind the scenes. Yes.

LAZEAR: Yes. And he'll tell you that he did. I think the issue here is the Fed has an important job, and its job is to maintain low inflation rates and to make sure that we have stable employment, and that's their job and I think that that's why most economist favoring independent Fed and I think that, you know, I'd like to see that continue.

BARTIROMO: Of course. Ed, it's great to see you this morning. Thanks so much.

LAZEAR: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Ed Lazear joining us. Coming up. A new home for Friends. Warner Media's upcoming streaming service HBO Max has its first big get. Then, team USA. The World Cup parade steps off today in New York City celebrating the women's national team's big win. We'll take you there live. Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Technology and media giants headed to Sun Valley, Idaho today for a big conference that will draw everybody from Apple CEO Tim Cook to Disney Head Bob Iger, and then some. Jackie DeAngelis is there on the ground with the very latest. Jackie, good morning to you.

JACKIE DEANGELIS, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: Good morning to you Maria. That's right, it's going to be the who's who of tech and tech and also media, they're coming together to have conversations about the industry but they also talk about politics, sports, philanthropy, and they bike and they hike here. And deals have been made in the past too. So this year, all eyes are on Shari Redstone because she arrived yesterday and everyone's wondering if there's going to be an announcement about a merger between Viacom and CBS.

And the second aspect of this is T-Mobile and Sprint. That's a merger waiting for regulatory approval. Obviously a lot of eyes on dish waiting to see if it's going to scoop some of those assets to set the pathway forward for that deal to happen. So, people are looking not only to try to grab a glimpse of Shari Redstone but Warren Buffett was spotted here yesterday, Sheryl Sandberg, Bobby Kotick, Lachlan Murdoch, the CEO of Fox Corp, parent of Fox Business as well.

Tim Cook, Jack Dorsey, you name it, they're not going to be at the social media summit tomorrow because they are all here in Idaho. But the theme this year, part of the conversation is about tech and media coming together and how those tech companies are sitting on a lot of cash and potentially looking to acquire and scoop up some of these media assets. Speaking of -- I want to give some streaming news because Netflix has announced that Friends will actually leave its streaming service, Friends is going to have a seat on Warner Media's new service that's launching next spring.

And it just gives you an idea of how things are moving along, within this space, Maria.

BARTIROMO: All right, Jackie. Great stuff. We'll be watching your reporting all day and thanks so much. Jackie DeAngelis in Idaho this morning. Coming up. Markets are waiting on the Fed. Chairman Jay Powell set to released his prepared testimony in 11 minutes, just before his testimony, before the House Financial Services Committee. We will bring you those comments as soon as the embargo is lifted and that's 10 minutes.

Then in women in the workforce. I'm speaking to one CEO who's worked with big names like Google and General Mills, now launching her own FinTech startup. She'll join us on set. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Women in the workforce. A new FinTech startup looking to revolutionize the payments industry with the first ever direct sales force made up of women. Park Place Payments launching today after announcing it's raised more than a million dollars in seed funding. Joining us right now is the founder and CEO, Park Place Payments Founder and CEO, Sam Ettus. Same, it's great to have you on the show.

SAM ETTUS, FOUNDER AND CEO, PARK PLACE PAYMENTS: Thanks so much.

BARTIROMO: I feel like FinTech in this specific corner of FinTech payments is all the rage. A lot of companies are trying to really get that consumer to get digital payments through them. How are you going to compete?

ETTUS: Well, nobody is using cash anymore. So, as payments grows, the interesting thing is that the industry really hasn't evolved as much as it should have on the service side. So what we found is that all of the merchants and business owners are desperately seeking transparency and this industry has been functioning a lot more like the used car sales industry where everyone is charging a different rate, there's all these hidden fees.

So, we've brought transparency through the sales the force of professional women who are incredible and these are women who formerly really have been on the sidelines and it's this on top labor force of women who maybe only had alternatives like selling makeup and skincare to their friends and now they're selling financial services in their communities.

BELL: How do you get them comfortable with selling financial services because it can be a daunting industry?

ETTUS: Well, we have an online course, it's called Park Place Academy and we train women from across the country to sell in their ZIP code. So once they have the sales skills, it's really -- it's all about relationship building. And so, these are relationships most of them have already had. They have relationships with their dentist, with their toy store, with their bookstore. Everyone in their community, they're hair salon.

And so they're selling into their community and then they become almost like the payment's mayor of that ZIP code. They come to the Chamber of Commerce meetings, everyone knows them. And it's actually really fun to get to know all the business owners in your community and you're helping Main Street at the same time as you're making a lot of money.

ROSCHELLE: Sam, how did you find the money-raising process to be and do you think there is a lot of money out there for these types of FinTech start-ups?

ETTUS: I do. I think that you really have to be smart about it. For us, we really focus on angel investors who were very seasoned. We didn't want to raise easy money in this first round because they didn't know if we actually need to raise money again next year. It's not a capital intensive industry. So what we did was we focused on these very seasoned institutional invest -- sorry, angel investors not Uncle Bob, it was all people who have a lot of experience, who care passionately about not only making money but helping women at the same time.

So, it was actually a really great process. I would say that our conversion rate of people we talked to, to people who gave was very high. And it's because it's really exciting to be part of a company that's, you know, doing really well and doing good at the same time.

BARTIROMO: Good stuff. Yes.

BELL: I was just going to say as female, it's sometimes hard to get those meetings, so with the angel servers, so how did you make that happen? That's pretty impressive.

ETTUS: Well, I was really focused on getting a very diverse group of investors. So we wanted people of color and we wanted more than half women and we got there. So, it's really just word of mouth and networking and talking to anyone you can talk to and making sure that you have people in the round who are believing in you in the mission, and also care about investing in something that's going to do really well.

And, you know, women have a greater return investment in terms of investment money than men do, if you look at the stats. And so, I think people are realizing that investing in women is investing smart.

BARTIROMO: I love it. Samantha, congrats.

ETTUS: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Thanks so much for joining us. Samantha Ettus joining us there. Coming up. Markets are waiting on the Fed. Chairman Jay Powell set to release his prepared testimony just moments from now, just ahead of the appearance before the House Financial Services Committee. We will have the embargoed comments right after this break. Stay with us.

Then, the battle for the border. A new data shows a dip in apprehensions along the southwest border last month. What officials say is driving that decline. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Wednesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it Wednesday, July 10th. Your top stories right now just before 8:30 a.m. on the East Coast. Breaking news this morning, we are waiting on Fed Chairman Jay Powell. His prepared remarks are out right now as day one of his two-day testimony is about to get underway. Ahead of the testimony, futures right now pointing to a lower opening. We want to get right to Edward Lawrence, he's got the embargoed news. Edward.

EDWARD LAWRENCE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK REPORTER: Yes, Maria. The Federal Reserve Chairman will tell the House Financial Services Committee the economy remains solid, but the 3.1 percent GDP growth, he says, that we saw on the first quarter, business investment had slowed, he says, in the second quarter. Powell will tell the committee that since the last fed meeting, in uncertainty over trade and concerns about the slowing global economy weighs on the U.S. economy.

He says that inflation pressures will look muted going forward. Now the Fed estimates that inflation is running about 1.5 percent for PCE, it's about 1.6 percent for core PCE. He says the Fed will carefully monitor both inflation and outside risk to the U.S. economy. Now Powell mentions specifically trade developments, the federal debt ceiling, and Brexit has possible policy issues that need to be resolved to fix that uncertainty in this market.

He also will acknowledge that several members of the FOMC saw a more -- or a case for a more accommodative monetary policy going forward. His testimony focuses on that inflation and crosscurrents in the economy. And you could really see it walking a line in the testimony where there is a case to keep the rate exactly where it is, also a case to see that the rate could be cut, the Federal Reserve Chairman is clearly walking that line, maneuvering a very divided Federal Reserve. Maria.

BARTIROMO: All right, Edward. Yes, we're parsing through these comments now and on the downside, he says since the May meeting, crosscurrents have remerged, creating greater uncertainty. So these crosscurrents he's talking about or the slowing global economy and the uncertainties over trade, let's take a look at markets here and see if we've had -- we've got a turn complete around. We had a negative performance before these embargoed came out and we're looking at now the futures pointing to a gain in the -- in the -- in the -- in the market. Dow Industrials up 14, S&P up three, NASDAQ up 20.

Real quick, Dagen McDowell, your take on these comments that were embargoed until now.

MCDOWELL: He touches on Jay Powell does what we've been talking about on this program if there's some worry spots in the U.S. economy, it would be housing investment declining in the first quarter, and decreasing again in second quarter, and also manufacturing output declining in first quarter and decreasing again in the second quarter, those are the two worrisome spots in U.S. economy.

It looks like he's, again, laying the groundwork for a rate cut but maybe not in the month of July. There are enough bright spots in this economy for the Fed to watch and wait.

BARTIROMO: Yes. He said the consumer spending is now running at a solid pace, but you're right, it's housing and manufacturing, those are the two weak spots and the uncertainty around trade. Markets have turned around, we're looking at a positive performance, let's get down to Gerri Willis. She's on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange right now with a reaction there, Gerri.

GERRI WILLIS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hey, Maria. That's right. So, these guys down here, they see this as a positive and you can tell by looking at the futures right this very minute. We were negative as much as 58 points in the break before the news came out, now we're up 15 points. Look, people down here don't expect the Federal Reserve Chairman to draw a line between today and what he's going to do on the 31st, but, boy, he almost did.

Remember at the last meeting he said an ounce of prevention is worth than a pound of cure, looks headed in that direction. Here's what traders were telling me this morning. One of the things they were interested in seeing him say is talking about the yield curve inversion and naturally trying to fix that, which would mean a rate cut, defending independence, and the idea, some guys down here re like it doesn't matter what he says, there could be an overreaction to anything he does and say.

But as you can see, the takeaway right now is ultimately positive, the markets are saying, you know, this seems to be a statement that the global economy is weakening, therefore more likely to do a rate cut. Maria, back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right, Gerri. Thanks so much. Yes, I thought it was interesting that he starts his commentary by thanking the Congress, highlighting the independence of the Federal Reserve and thanking Congress for that independence. A lot here to go through, obviously these -- this has impacted markets and I want to turn to the battle at the border while also looking at the economy.

Apprehensions at the Southern Border are down 28 percent last month. According to the Department Homeland Security, the decline coming after the Mexican Government agreed to step up its own immigration enforcement in an effort to avoid heightened tariffs. Earlier in the program, I spoke with Vice President Mike Pence's Chief-of-Staff, Marc Short, about the decline in apprehensions. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARCH SHORT, VICE PRESIDENT MIKE PENCE'S CHIEF OF STAFF: We've had more assistance from Mexico in the last month than we've had from Congressional Democrats in 10 years in trying to secure our border. The 28 percent decline is really about attributed to Mexico. We have so many challenges on ours laws where one of the things that the Vice President and Secretary Pompeo helped negotiate last month with Mexico is a remain in Mexico policy. Many of your viewers may not know this, other than Mexican rule that says if you're not from Mexico, we can't return you back, we have to keep you here in the United States and go through the adjudication process.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Yes. It's a really important point he made. Joining me right now is House Minority Whip, Louisiana Congressman Steve Scalise. Congressman, it's always a pleasure to see you. Thanks so much for joining me.

REP. STEVE SCALISE (R-LA): Morning. Good to be with you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: So before I get to those apprehensions, I got to get your take on the economy ahead of this Congressional interview with Jay Powell. We have his embargoed comments right now and while he says that the current expansion is in 11th year -- eleventh year. He also says that housing investment declined in the first quarter, decreased again in the second quarter, and manufacturing output declined in the first quarter, decreased again in the second quarter. How worried are you about these headwinds in the economy right now?

SCALISE: Well, you know, I think you're seeing two different things happen. Just last week, you saw over 240,000 new jobs created, so there are still good signs. I do think we need to get beyond these trade talks, wars, get rid of the tariffs, but ultimately get to better agreements for America.

It needs to start, Maria, as you know this, with USMCA. There's no reason why that bill hasn't come to the floor and passed already. Speaker Pelosi needs to schedule that for a vote. That'll help create more jobs and remove some of the uncertainty, and then let us all focus our attention on China.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

SCALISE: Not just America, but all of our friends around the world want us to take on China, because they know we're the only ones who can. And if we do that, and if we get that resolved and get beyond trade issues that are hanging a cloud over our economy, I think the best is yet to come.

BARTIROMO: It's a really important point that you make. In fact, the Chairman of the Fed said that he sees these crosscurrents, first time he's used that word, crosscurrents such as trade tensions and concerns about the global growth, that's been weighing on the economic activity and the outlook according to Powell, who will say this when he testifies to the Financial Services Committee coming up in a couple of hours here.

On the apprehensions, Congressman, what can you tell us? Has Mexico been a real mover in terms of getting those apprehensions down?

SCALISE: They truly have, and you heard Marc Short talk about it as well. I met with Secretary of Homeland Security a few days ago to talk about the crisis, what things he needs from Congress that Congress wasn't doing, finally starting to get them some relief. But he made the point to say that when Mexico finally engaged, President Trump had hung those tariffs over their head. They ultimately said, "We will help with the crisis." They put thousands of their own agents at their Southern Border. And it's had over 20 percent drop in people coming across the Mexican southern border illegally.

We still have too high of a number coming over right now, and the big thing and even Mexican officials tells us this, Maria, it's the Broken Asylum Laws in America. Which are a magnet telling people to come here illegally, they know they can read from a script. Many of them, by the way, have turned downs asylum in Mexico.

So, how can you have a credible claim for asylum when you turned it down from another country you came through? Yet they're coming here in droves, in many cases 3,000 or 4,000 people a day illegally. They're abusing young kids in many cases by bringing them over, because they know that that's their ticket in. They get a -- they get a certificate literally to be here for at least five years before a court date. And what the secretary told me is over 75 percent of those people don't show up for the court date five years later, this is a broken system that needs to be fixed.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

SCALISE: It takes Congressional action. You need to change the law. President Trump has identified that he wants to so solve -- we need to get it so quickly.

BARTIROMO: Well, that's what I was going to say. Isn't the onus on you and your colleagues? I mean you've to make the changes in the Congress in terms of the asylum standards.

SCALISE: Absolutely. And, look, the president's pushed the envelope as far as he can. He's done some things by executive action that had a positive impact. He's worked with Mexico.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

SCALISE: And got Mexico to help and engage, which has had a positive impact, but it's still -- when Jeh Johnson, the president -- the -- President Obama's Homeland Security Secretary is saying how bad it is today at the border, that tells you how bad it is, and yet Pelosi doesn't want to address the problem. She wants it as a political issue, so she won't bring any bill to the floor to solve this problem. But, look, I think people are fed up with this. They're looking at it, they're watching.

Every Democrat on the presidential stage, saying that they want free taxpayer benefits, free healthcare for people here illegally when seniors are paying more and waiting in longer lines, when people with preexisting conditions in many cases are paying a $10,000 deductible, and they want to give it away for me to people, illegally.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

SCALISE: I think that people are watching this.

BARTIROMO: Well, they all read said when they say, you know - the question was do your -- does your governing include giving healthcare to illegals, they all said yes. They're -- they raised their hand.

SCALISE: Every one of them.

BARTIROMO: Let me ask you, Marc Short said earlier on the program that he's expecting Nancy Pelosi to being the USMCA bill down for a vote in the fall. Is that what you're expecting or it is not happening this year?

SCALISE: Well, I think it's definitely possible that that happens. I'd like to see that happen. We will be willing to work. I've already got a whip team in place specifically for USMCA.

Kevin Brady, the head of the -- the Republican head of the Ways and Means Committee and I have already met with our teams. We'll be ready to help deliver the lion's share of the votes, but it's a big win for the whole country. It's not just a Republican win, Democrats win, the unions win.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

SCALISE: America is better off with USMCA than current law -- current NAFTA. We've got to get it done, let's create more jobs in our economy.

BARTIROMO: And one of the issues with NAFTA was wages, you know, companies would put their production in Mexico and pay a fraction of what they had to pay in America.

Let me ask you about the minimum wage battle because that sort of dovetails on all of this. New data from the Congressional Budget Office says it examined the House Democrat's plan for a federal $15.00 minimum wage mandate, finding that a $15.00 an hour minimum wage would eliminate roughly 1.3 million jobs in the United States. Explain that to us, Congressman.

SCALISE: Yes, Maria. It even gets worse than that, but Speaker Pelosi wants to bring this bill to the floor, that would eviscerate millions of jobs. We've seen in that same CBO report as many as 3.7 million jobs in America would go away. That's the entire state of Oklahoma.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

SCALISE: That's how massive their job loss would be. They don't address it at all, they're not concerned about that. They recognize it's a real problem for them. They might -- they might have trouble bringing that bill to the floor, because so many Democrats are afraid to vote for a bill that will eliminate millions of jobs. And in that same report, Maria, the CBO talks about how it will push millions more -- million -- millions more Americans below the poverty line.

So, they will literally create more families in poverty in America with that bill, and we've got wage growth growing right now without that bill, because there's a shortage of workers, as you know. With millions of openings for jobs -- good-paying jobs, with really good wages that are growing, why would they want to go and bring a bill that's going to not only destroy that job growth, but literally lead to the evisceration of 3.7 million jobs the entire state of Oklahoma?

BARTIROMO: That's incredible, 3.7 million jobs, that's obviously so much worse than about what we even thought. So, Congressman, what's your answer to the skeptics who say, "Look, we still have an income and inequality problem"?

SCALISE: Well, what I say is go look at what's happening right now in the economy. We're seeing the lowest unemployment amongst African Americans, amongst Hispanics in the history of our country. We're seeing wage growth go up, Maria, and it had been stagnant for over eight years. Under Obama for eight years, every single quarter, you have less than two percent growth.

Now we're finally seeing growth really high, we're seeing wages go up, let's get more of that, let's have more wage growth, not less. Why would you want to eliminate that? And look at this, Maria, in the last few years we've seen women-owned small businesses increase by 50 percent. Why would you want to bring policies that are going to destroy that, that are going to undermine that?

So, I think this shows the country the big divide between Republicans and Democrats in Washington. Most Democrats in America don't want to see their wages evaporate, they don't want some of the things that the Democrats are proposing like the Green New Deal, and Medicare for All, which eliminates the entire private health insurance market --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

SCALISE: -- with free insurance for people here illegally. And, again, shows you the big divide in Washington. There's a disconnect between Nancy Pelosi and middle America all across this country.

BARTIROMO: Well, there's also a disconnect between Nancy Pelosi and Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, so there's a disconnect within the -- within the party.

SCALISE: It's a shame to see.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Congressman, it's good to have you on the program. You mentioned small business and women, we just had one of them on the show. You're right, that's where you're seeing lots of job creation. We'll talk more about it. Congressman, thank you.

SCALISE: Let's keep that growth coming. Thanks, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Steve Scalise joining us there in D.C. Coming up, Team USA, the World Cup parades steps off today in New York City, celebrating the women's national team's big win. Stuart Varney weighs in next, then we will take you there live to check out all the action. But first, we've got a special update right now from The Tennis Channel.

DANI KLUPENGER, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK REPORTER: Welcome back to another Tennis Channel Court Report. For FOX Business, I'm Dani Klupenger. Tuesday at Wimbledon saw the Women's Quarterfinals in action, and while former world number one moved on, Simona Halep, moved on and Elina Svitolina became the first Ukrainian woman to reach a grand slam semi- finals, the story was once again Serena Williams.

In her first match of the day, Serena defeated fellow American Alison Riske in a tightly contested three-set match. Serena even admitted this one wasn't easy.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SERENA WILLIAMS, TENNIS PLAYER: No, I just needed to just fight. Alison was -- I mean she played so great throughout whole tournament, she's beaten so many amazing players that has been -- players that had great years and, you know, she was not giving it to me. I needed to step up and take it, and that's what I had to do.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

KLUPENGER: But Serena's work was not done. She came back out to center court for mixed doubles with Andy Murray, this time winning in straight sets. Don't forget, you can catch coverage of the Men's Quarterfinals Wednesday on Tennis Channel at 4:00 p.m. Eastern.

BARTIROMO: Well, partisan politics getting in the way of a great American win. Joining me right now, the host of "VARNEY & CO." Stuart Varney to weigh in. Big parade today, Stu.

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes, and I will be cheering them on, believe me. I think they're a great team, they prayed -- played brilliant soccer.

BARTIROMO: Yes, they did.

VARNEY: They're the best in the world, case closed. I just hate to see politics intruding here. You know, I really don't like it when the captain of the American Team says, "No, she's not going to White House," and then in an appearance on CNN last night, she -- he -- she basically tells the world, oh, she'd love to go and meet AOC and Speaker Pelosi, and she'd love to go and see Mr. Schumer, but, no, will not go to the White House because she detests President Trump."

I want to watch soccer. I want to see the greatest team in the world play soccer. I don't want to have in the back of my mind what's going on with politics here.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

VARNEY: And, frankly, I think the Democrats have grabbed hold of the World Cup and are now running it as a sideshow to back up their policies.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

VARNEY: I don't like that at all. I'm sorry, I just don't like it.

BARTIROMO: It's very sad.

VARNEY: Yes, totally.

BARTIROMO: I agree with you. And, by the way, did the President invite them yet?

VARNEY: I don't believe he has yet specifically.

BARTIROMO: No, but she says she's not going anyway. OK. Well, there you go.

VARNEY: No, she's not going anyway.

BARTIROMO: Stu, I know you'll have more of this in 10 --

VARNEY: But what about --

BARTIROMO: -- minutes.

VARNEY: I know, I just what about the rest of the team? Does she speak for everybody here?

BARTIROMO: Well, that's a good point.

VARNEY: Come on.

BARTIROMO: That is a good point, because remember there was that other player who made sure that the flag wasn't stepped on. She picked up the flag, the American Flag, after Rapinoe just sort of like threw it aside.

VARNEY: Yes. Right.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

VARNEY: Oh, yes, yes. Yes. I -- it's divisive.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

VARNEY: We should not be dividing at a time like this. You want to unite in support of a brilliant team.

BARTIROMO: That's true.

VARNEY: Come on.

BARTIROMO: Stu, I know that. You are right. Thank you so much.

VARNEY: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: We'll hear more in 10 minutes. Thank you. "VARNEY & CO." begins top of the hour, 9:00 a.m. Eastern right MORNINGS WITH MARIA, but first, we're going to take you live to the World Cup parade in New York City, check out the festivities, back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Hooray for Team USA, celebrating a big World Cup victory today in New York City with a ticker tape parade throughout Lower Manhattan. Kristina Partsinevelos is covering the story. She's down there in New York City. Kristina, good morning.

KRISTINA PARTSINEVELOS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, Maria. What a perfect day for a parade. The sun is shining, we are just north of Battery Park. The parade will start 9:30 Eastern Time. We'll run up from Battery Park all the way to city hall along the Canyon of Heroes. According to the city, there's been about 206 parades along this pass, celebrating championships, victories, athletes, you name it, and right now, what you're seeing is the start of the parade. It starts at 9:30.

There are some motorcyclists over there, female motorcyclists, one of them drove by us and said she is starting with her story, they are making her story, so we do know a lot of people have been lined up according to the city as of Monday. People -- the public was able to get passes. Those were taken within seconds. A lot of people are excited. Another man told me he came all the way from Las Vegas to celebrate the fourth win, the World Cup win for the U.S. Women's National Team since 1991. It's called a ticker-tape parade.

A lot of our viewers probably know this, the ticker-tape often used back in the day for stocks. You print out some information on there. So, today, expect confetti absolutely everywhere. People can throw it on to the crowds, and we're going to be here bringing you all the information. Of course there's going to be a scrum very soon with the mayor perhaps. We will be discussing equal pay, perhaps we'll discussing just the situation, the political situation, but, overall, the people that I've met so far here are just as excited to celebrate their national U.S. Women's Team and we're going to bring you all the information as of 9:30 Eastern time. Back to you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Awesome. It looks great down there, Kristina. Thanks so much. We will be checking back with you throughout the day.

PARTSINEVELOS: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Kristina Partsinevelos in New York. Still ahead, futures are rebounding, now up in the triple digits on the Fed Chairman Jay Powell comments that we brought you 30 minutes ago. We got final thoughts from this all-star panel when we come right back as the Dow is up now 111 points. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Thirty minutes away from the opening bell. Futures now up 100 points on Fed Chairman Jay Powell's prepared testimony. We brought you the embargoed comments earlier in the program at 8:30. Let's go through them to see really what's moving this market. Mitch, you have a -- you have a favorite in here.

ROSCHELLE: Yes. In the last paragraph, it says Fed Chairman acknowledges that some FOMC members, "Saw that the case for a somewhat more accommodative monetary policy had strengthened," and I think that's one of the lines that the market's hanging their hat on, that. And if you look backwards, the FOMC members were sort of 50/50 on whether or not to cut so this may be perceived that it's tilted and it's more than just 50/50.

BARTIROMO: People are reading this as we're going to get a cut.

BELL: Yes, I absolutely think that. What stuck out to me is he says government policy issues have yet to be resolved, including trade developments, federal debt ceiling, and Brexit, meaning that fed cuts aren't necessarily going to save us from these policy issues that need to be resolved.

BARTIROMO: Well, he's obviously listening to Dagen McDowell. You also pointed out earlier, Dagen, that it's housing and manufacturing of their weak spots right now that he's focused on.

MCDOWELL: Right. They continue to weaken in the second quarter. But, again, I don't get it. How does a quarter point or a half point cut by the Federal Reserve really rescue us from all of these problems, particularly the weakness overseas?

BARTIROMO: It's trade, though. I like the fact that he brings in crosscurrents have emerged and that's the trade uncertainty.

MCDOWELL: That's his robust.

BARTIROMO: Yes, exactly.

MCDOWELL: Or contrastive trade discussions.

BARTIROMO: Patience. Patience.

ROSCHELLE: But as a voter, sometimes crosscurrents push you in the right direction also.

BARTIROMO: Yes. It looks like it's pushing in the right direction today. Market's up 100 points. Have a great day, everybody. Dagen McDowell, Mitch Roschelle, Lindsey Bell, great show, that'll do it for us. "VARNEY & CO." begins right now. Stu, take it away.

VARNEY: I will indeed.

urn:contentItem:5WWJ-V221-JC11-138W-00000-00Reps. Velazquez, Porter Urge Financial Stability Oversight Council to Oversee Tech Giants2019-08-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:21:31ZLexisNexisReps. Velazquez, Porter Urge Financial Stability Oversight Council to Oversee Tech GiantsTargeted News ServiceWASHINGTON

Rep. Nydia M. Velazquez, D-New York, issued the following news release:

Rep. Nydia M. Velazquez (D-NY) and Rep. Katie Porter (D-CA) have written to the Secretary of the U.S. Treasury as head of the Financial Stability Oversight Council (FSOC), encouraging the Council to consider designating the three leading cloud-based computing storage providers for the financial industry as systemically important financial market utilities (SIFMUs).

The letter follows last month's data breach at Capital One Financial Corporation, which exposed the personal information of approximately 106 million Capital One credit card customers and applicants. The personal data of millions of Americans that Capital One was storing was being hosted in a cloud provided by Amazon Web Services, and was breached by a former Amazon employee. This recent incident raises new and serious questions about banks and financial companies' dependence on cloud services, profoundly worrying lawmakers about the data economy's risks to public safety and financial stability.

"I was appalled to learn that millions of hard-working Americans' personal data had been compromised. Banks and financial institutions' increasing reliance on cloud service providers for their data storage needs increases the risk these systems pose to the safety and stability of our nation's financial system," said Velazquez. "I am proud to partner with Rep. Porter to ensure the data integrity of our financial institutions is maintained."

"Too often we are trying to solve yesterday's problems tomorrow, instead of making policy that prevents tomorrow's problems from happening in the first place," said Porter. "As our financial system increasingly relies on cloud computing and other forms of technology, we need to ensure the proper 21st century safeguards are in place to prevent another financial crisis."

The letter calls on the FSOC to consider designating Amazon Web Services, Microsoft Azure and Google Cloud as SIFMUs under the Title VIII of the Dodd-Frank Act. A SIFMU designation would subject the tech firms to enhanced oversight by the Federal Reserve to ensure a cloud failure of a leading financial institution would not create a catastrophic risk to the nation's financial system.

A .pdf of the letter is online here and the full text is below.

August 22, 2019

The Honorable Steven T. Mnuchin

Secretary

U.S. Department of the Treasury

1500 Pennsylvania Avenue, N.W.

Washington, D.C. 20220

Secretary Mnuchin:

We write to request that the Financial Stability Oversight Council (FSOC or the Council) convene a meeting and consider designating the three leading providers of cloud-based storage systems for the financial industry: Amazon Web Services, Microsoft Azure, and Google Cloud--as systemically important financial market utilities (SIFMUs).

Last month's data breach at Capital One Financial Corporation (Capital One) was the most recent in a string of incidences demonstrating the dangerous breadth of banks' and financial institutions' increasing reliance on cloud computing--and the reach of Amazon Web Services in particular. While it has been determined that an error by Capital One enabled the breach, the incident raises new and serious questions about banks' and financial institutions' dependence on cloud services for their data needs--and the risks these systems pose to the safety and stability of the financial system.

Title VIII of the Dodd-Frank Act was enacted to promote stability in the financial system, in part by granting the FSOC the ability to conduct enhanced oversight of Financial Market Utilities (FMUs). Per the Federal Reserve: "In cases where, among other things, a failure or a disruption to the functioning of an FMU could create, or increase, the risk of significant liquidity or credit problems spreading among financial institutions or markets and thereby threaten the stability of the U.S. financial system, the FMU may be designated as systemically important." Title VIII authorizes the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve to, among other powers, conduct examinations of, take enforcement action against, and prescribe risk management standards for entities designated as systemically important FMUs, or SIFMUs.[1]

According to the FSOC, it must consider the following four factors when analyzing the appropriateness of a SIFMU designation: "(1) the aggregate monetary value of transactions processed by the FMU; (2) the aggregate exposure of the FMU to its counterparties; (3) the relationship, interdependencies, or other interactions of the FMU with other FMUs or payment, clearing, or settlement activities; and (4) the effect that the failure of or a disruption to the FMU would have on critical markets, financial institutions, or the broader financial system."[2] Though there are operational differences between cloud service providers and the eight existing SIFMUs, cloud services have become an essential element of our modern financial system and should be overseen commensurately.

First, though the cloud service providers at issue may not process monetary transactions directly, their operational stability underpins an increasing share of banks' central functions. For example, Bank of America Corporation intends to deliver 80 percent of its technological functions on virtual platforms and with public cloud infrastructure "within the next several years."[3] According to its Chief Technology Officer, Microsoft Azure "continues to see strong cloud adoption from the financial services industry, with more than 80 percent of the world's largest banks and more than 75 percent of the global systemically important financial institutions using Azure."[4] HSBC's Chief Information Officer expressed similar sentiments at Google's 2017 Next conference: "Apart from having the $2.4 trillion of assets on the balance sheet, we also have at the core of the company a massive asset in our data, and what's been happening in the last two to three years is a massive growth in the size of our data assets." HBSC uses Google Cloud; the volume of data held at the time of the conference was over 100 petabytes--or 100 million gigabytes.[5]

As data becomes increasingly monetized, hackers become more sophisticated, and firms put more data on servers or the cloud, these breaches are getting more severe. There have been over 9,000 data breaches made public since 2005, which have exposed over 11 billion records in the United States alone.[6] In 2005, 1.4 million credit card numbers and the names on those accounts, held by DSW Shoe Warehouse, were breached--the first time a breach compromised over a million records. In 2017, the Equifax breach exposed the personally identifiable information of 148 million people.[7] First reported in July of this year, a data breach at Capital One, which relies on Amazon Web Services for its data storage, compromised over 100 million Capital One customer accounts and credit card applications.[8] Though cloud service providers may not process monetary transactions like other SIFMUs, these firms provide the world's biggest banks with the technological foundation necessary to link to one another and other financial and commercial market participants, thereby helping to enable monetary and commercial transactions while simultaneously maintaining their clientele's most sensitive information and associated assets.

With regard to the second factor, though there is no direct financial exposure if the cloud fails, the counterparty exposure in the form of a failure to provide the cloud service--and the operational losses that stem from that failure--could be significant.

Third, the volatility of public confidence in cloud services and the necessity of data integrity to maintaining that confidence is common to all cloud service providers. A data breach or other disruptive event that shakes public perception of the trustworthiness of the cloud could discourage consumers from using cloud-reliant banks and potentially spur a bank run. Should any cloud service provider fail, public mistrust of the service would not be limited to that one company. Particularly given the rapid speed of technological development, enforcing appropriate safeguards is critical to maintaining continued public acceptance of the cloud.

Fourth, the effect of a disruption to a cloud services provider on the broader financial system could be catastrophic. According to a 2016 report by McKinsey, 100 percent of financial institutions use cloud services in some capacity.[9] In addition to financial institutions, our government has come to rely on Amazon Web Services for a massive share of its data storage needs: the Department of Defense holds a $10 billion cloud computing contract with Amazon Web Services, and NASA and the state of Arizona are also clients of AWS.[10] An Amazon Web Services cloud failure in particular would debilitate major swaths of the financial industry, basic government functions, and our national security.

It is important to note that not all four factors are weighted equally. According to the FSOC in its 2011 Rule describing the criteria the Council would consider in designating SIFMUs, "the two critical determinations for an FMU designation are: (1) Whether the failure of or a disruption to the functioning of the FMU now or in the future could create, or increase, the risk of significant liquidity or credit problems spreading among financial institutions or markets (the ''First Determination''); and (2) Whether the spread of such liquidity or credit problems among financial institutions or markets could threaten the stability of the financial system of the United States (the ''Second Determination'')."[11]

While not all banks have made public their cloud service providers, among major financial institutions, Capital One and Liberty Mutual use Amazon Web Services,[12] Bank of America uses Microsoft Azure,[13] and HSBC uses Google Cloud.[14] Fifty-seven percent of the cloud services market is cornered by those three providers: in the first quarter of this year, Amazon Web Services controlled 33 percent of the market, Microsoft Azure 16 percent, and Google Cloud 8 percent.[15] Given the technical nature of computing services, a firm like Bank of America would not be able to quickly transfer its cloud services to Amazon Web Services, should Microsoft Azure fail. In the interim, while the cloud was nonfunctional, the bank would be unable to perform up to 80 percent of its technological functions--potentially creating significant liquidity disruptions.[16] A lack of substitutability for the services provided by these very few firms creates systemic risk; a disruption at any major cloud computing platform would cause widespread and immediate harm and compromise the stability of the market.

Additionally, cloud services are not currently subject to an appropriate and enforced regulatory regime. In April, Federal Reserve examiners assessed an Amazon.com facility in Virginia,[17] using their limited power under the Bank Service Company Act to oversee nonbank vendors that provide the software to run banks' deposit and loan platforms.[18] "Chaperoned by an Amazon employee, they were allowed to review certain documents on Amazon laptops, but not allowed to take anything with them."[19] The perfunctory review of a handful of Amazon-selected documents over the course of a few hours, on-site, is not meaningful oversight. Without a dedicated regulatory regime proportional and tailored to their very unique structure and risks, cloud computing companies will continue to evade supervision.

Our concerns are shared by the world's major financial market regulators. In February of this year, the Financial Stability Board--an international body comprised of the G-20's central banks and supervisors--noted that Big Tech is invading the financial sector and could upend the stability of the market.[20] In April, top European Union financial regulators issued a report in which they advocated for legislation to monitor cloud computing services that are central to financial institutions. The supervisors highlighted the vulnerabilities implicit in the financial industry's heavy reliance on third parties and noted that their concerns are "especially acute with regard to cloud services."[21]

Given the serious and far-reaching risks inherent in our reliance on a handful of cloud service providers to maintain the basic functioning of our economy, we ask that you consider designating as SIFMUs the country's largest cloud service providers, including but not limited to Amazon Web Services, Google Cloud, and Microsoft Azure. Please respond by September 15th with a description of the FSOC's plan to consider these designations. If the Council will not evaluate the appropriateness of using its authority under 12 U.S.C. Sec. 5463 to regulate cloud computing providers, please respond with your reasoning.

Signed,
