urn:contentItem:5J0S-DBK1-DY0W-41J9-00000-00Republican Candidates Gear Up for Fox News Debate in Iowa; U.S. Futures Point to Gains; Facebook Stock Skyrockets as Mobile Drives Big Jump2016-01-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:21:31ZLexisNexisRepublican Candidates Gear Up for Fox News Debate in Iowa; U.S. Futures Point to Gains; Facebook Stock Skyrockets as Mobile Drives Big JumpLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, HOST, MORNINGS WITH MARIA: Good morning everybody, I'm Maria Bartiromo.

Welcome back, the top stories on this Thursday, January 28th at 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Republican candidates gearing up for tonight's debate in Iowa. The event hosted by our sister network, the Fox News channel.

It's the final GOP debate before the Iowa caucuses this upcoming Monday. Frontrunner, Donald Trump says he still won't participate in tonight's event.

He went on the "O'REILLY FACTOR" last night to explain his decision.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BILL O'REILLY, FOX NEWS: I --

DONALD TRUMP, CHAIRMAN & PRESIDENT, TRUMP ORGANIZATIONS & FOUNDER, TRUMP ENTERTAINMENT RESORTS: Right --

O'REILLY: Submit to you that you need to change and get away from the personal -- they hurt my feelings, are unfair to me.

And they get about them, the folks, not about you. And you elevate them to a place where you could win this if you do that. Am I crazy?

TRUMP: You're not crazy at all, but it is about them, it's about making America great again.

That's why I'm doing this. It's not because I want the position, it's because I know the potential of this country, how great the country can be.

Our leader is not doing the job.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Be sure to tune in tonight for the Fox News-Google debate, beginning at 7:00 p.m. Eastern on the Fox News channel.

Let's look at markets right here. Futures pointing to modest gains at the opening of trading.

Take a look, we've been back and forth between positive and negative territories this morning, we are expecting a higher opening for the Dow about 40 points high.

Nasdaq looking good, up 33 points, of course the Federal Reserve yesterday raised questions about the next time it will be able to raise interest rates.

Same with the economy did in fact slowdown at the end of last year. In Europe, markets are lower this morning across the board.

Take a look, down between two-thirds of 1 percent and one and a third percent. The Dax index in Germany down.

Hundred and thirty five points right now, that's the low of the morning, down better than 1 percent. And in Asia overnight, tough night in China.

The Shanghai composite down nearly 3 percent on the session, that set the tone. The Nikkei average down three-quarters of 1 percent.

Facebook, the stock to watch today. The social media giant handily beating earnings expectations.

Revenue soared better than 50 percent in the fourth quarter from a year earlier, driven by mobile advertising.

The stock jumping in the pre-market this morning, Facebook up sharply right now. Growing concern this morning about the Zika virus.

The United Nations is holding an emergency meeting on Monday to determine whether the virus should be deemed an international health emergency.

This as new cases of the Zika virus confirmed in the United States just this morning. There are now at least six cases including New York.

Republican presidential candidates getting ready to face off tonight in the Fox News debate in Iowa.

The last GOP debate before Monday's Iowa caucuses. Blake Burman is in Des Moines right now with the preview of what to expect tonight. Blake.

BLAKE BURMAN, FOX BUSINESS: Hi there, Maria, good morning to you. Donald Trump continues to maintain steadfastly that he will not be here at the Fox News debate tonight, later tonight here in Des Moines.

This is still an incredibly important debate for so many different reasons. Not only is it the final debate in the lead up until the Iowa caucuses on Monday night.

But also the first debate here in Iowa as well, over the issues for Iowa voters will be front and center.

There will be 11 other candidates here guaranteed later tonight. The 9:00 debate has seven candidates on that stage.

Cruz and Rubio will be front and center, they'll be flanked by Carson and Bush, Christie and Kasich, and Rand Paul makes his return to the 9:00 debate stage.

But this all kicks off at 7:00 with four candidates: Fiorina, Huckabee and Santorum. Jim Gilmore also returns to this debate.

I was speaking with an adviser yesterday of Ted Cruz, and that adviser told me that his campaign feels that Cruz will be the one receiving the cross- fire now.

Because if Trump isn't there, they say, you know what? People shoot up in these debates, Cruz is running second in the polls, they expect their guy to get a lot of the heat tonight.

Still, they told me, Maria, Donald Trump will not going to pass.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. TED CRUZ (R), TEXAS: But at the end of the day, it's not really the Donald who is afraid of Megyn.

It's not that he's afraid of Mark or Sean or Rush. It's not that he's afraid of me. He's afraid of you.

He doesn't want to answer questions from the men and women of Iowa about how his record doesn't match what he's selling.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: Things still look good for Trump here. A new "Wall Street Journal" poll out this morning shows he has 32 percent support from Iowa caucus, though rose at 7 points ahead of Cruz, Rubio comes in at 18 as well.

That poll also shows in the other early states of New Hampshire and South Carolina that Trump lead big. Maria, back to to you.

BARTIROMO: All right, Blake, thanks so much Blake Burman. And joining us right now is former Senate Majority leader George Mitchell and former RNC chairman and former Mississippi Governor Haley Barbour.

Good to see you both gentlemen, thanks so much for joining us.

GEORGE MITCHELL, FORMER SENATE MAJORITY LEADER: Thank you, Maria --

BARTIROMO: Senator, let me kick this off with you. What's your take on what's going on right now?

Is Trump not showing up tonight, is that going to be good for him or do you think he loses in this?

MITCHELL: I think it's probably not good for him, the more important question is, will it derail his efforts in it, I doubt that.

BARTIROMO: So, it won't be good for him, but it won't derail him either?

MITCHELL: No, I don't think it would. Ted Cruz himself said, I think it was yesterday that, if Trump wins Iowa and then goes on to win New Hampshire which proves likely, he'll be unstoppable.

And on that I think Senator Cruz may be right.

BARTIROMO: Wow, governor, what do you think?

HALEY BARBOUR, FORMER MISSISSIPPI GOVERNOR: Well, obviously, Trump thinks it's good for him or he wouldn't be doing it.

This is -- I don't think this is about his feelings being hurt. I think he made the calculation he's got more to lose by being in the debate than not being in the debate.

But we'll see. He's -- if the polling is to be believed, he's got a solid lead in both of these states.

I don't think anybody has got it in the bag. I don't think the idea that somebody is inevitable if they win both these debates is accurate, but I guess, he gets a mighty powerful momentum --

BARTIROMO: Yes --

BARBOUR: If he wins both of them.

BARTIROMO: I think this is a really good point. But let me ask you about what he said about you governor, because he was asked about you with George Stephanopoulos.

And he said, look, Haley Barbour, he's an old-time politician, he's been up in my office looking for money many times, Trump says.

He's an old-time politician who is losing his grip. Frankly, I haven't heard the name Haley Barbour ever mentioned in a year and a half, and the reason that me and Ted Cruz are in the lead is because of that.

What do you think about this governor?

BARBOUR: Well, he's certainly right that I'm old. But the fact is, George Stephanopoulos, the next day apologized for telling Donald Trump that I had said something about him that I didn't say.

In fact, I hadn't said anything about him. I've only met the guy twice in my life and one time he took me to a heavyweight championship fight in Atlantic City when I was RNC chairman back in the -- back in the '90s.

I've stayed out of this just like I did in 2008 and 2012 as a former national party chairman.

That's what I have intended to do and I've done it again. I'm going to support the nominee of the party, because I don't think our country can stay four more years with Obama's policies.

And that's what we'll get if we elect Hillary Clinton or Bernie Sanders. But that's what I'm going to do.

I'm going to follow Reagan's 11th commandment, I was a political director to (INAUDIBLE) and Ronald Reagan, that's what he preached and practiced.

And that's what I start to practice --

BARTIROMO: Yes, you're right. Stephanopoulos apologized because basically he was starting this thing between the two of you, and you didn't even say anything.

It was actually --

BARBOUR: That is right --

BARTIROMO: Henry Barbour, the former -- your nephew and --

BARBOUR: That's exactly right --

BARTIROMO: A Republican strategist, so he said it, he brings up your name as if you said it, and Trump lashes at you for no reason.

But Senator Mitchell --

BARBOUR: OK --

BARTIROMO: The idea that Bernie Sanders is in the lead in Iowa on the Dem side and Trump is in the lead on the Republican side.

What does it say about our country right now?

MITCHELL: Well, I think there's a lot of frustration, anger, that happens whenever the economy turns down.

The President who campaigns provide an outlet for frustration that people feel. Particularly those who aren't moving up in the new economy.

We figured out a way to encourage innovation, we have the technological revolutions which we're now passing.

We'll be seeing in the future as important in human affairs as it was the industrial revolution.

But we haven't figured out how to replace the jobs that had been lost. What I call the working man middle income jobs.

Factory worker who could support a wife and two children. And that frustration will continue for a long time and it's finding its expression now in the presidential campaign on both sides.

But I think you're going to see a closely contested election in the general election. The country is pretty much divided.

The parties, well, I think generally unite, you heard Hillary say he'll support whoever the nominee is.

BARTIROMO: Right --

MITCHELL: And an interesting way, Trump is the nominee will help the Democrats unite and Secretary Clinton as the Democratic nominee will help the Republicans unite.

So, although, history isn't much of a guide in this election, history tells us that you can have a hotly contested nominee processes and still find the parties coming together.

BARTIROMO: Are you surprised Bernie Sanders is beating Hillary in Iowa?

MITCHELL: No, I think that he's beating Hillary in the polls, and as you see from the poll results, it's overwhelmingly among young people.

The question still is whether they will turn out to vote. But I think once you get past New Hampshire, he isn't in his favorable territory as he is in these first two states.

BARTIROMO: Governor, what about you? You know, you've been the chairman of the RNC, what do you think in terms of how this plays out next several months?

How important is Iowa followed by New Hampshire? What are the other states that you think will really give us a sense of who in fact people are voting for?

BARBOUR: Well, when you go down to the south, you'll see if you get different results, but I'm not sure that you will.

But I think George Mitchell makes very important points. The country is very evenly divided.

But there's so much polarity. There's so much division and it is because as he said, people in our country are dissatisfied.

And it's not the right or the left, it's both. You see it in both parties, and it's because nearly two-thirds of Americans think that the country is going in the wrong direction.

And that you thought that for two or three years. This is not some phenomenon because something bad happened last week or last month or last quarter.

People have been very dissatisfied about the economy, about national security, about so many things that it's manifesting now that people say, you know, that they're mad at everybody in Washington.

Hence Bernie Sanders, hence Donald Trump, Ted Cruz, both parties though.

BARTIROMO: So, who do you think has the best plan to fix some of these things then? I mean, you know, Senator Mitchell is talking about automation, technology displacing people.

Obviously wages haven't moved. There are a lot of issues that are upsetting people.

BARBOUR: And very rarely is that talked about in the news coverage. Mostly, it's about personality, it's about polling, it's about tactics.

We need more of the debate to be about. Here is the problem, here is my plan to fix the problem, and frankly, the candidates that talked the most about that, Kasich and Bush and Christie on our side, they get the least coverage.

BARTIROMO: You're right --

BARBOUR: Donald Trump gets ten times more coverage than everybody else combined without ever really talking about anything and any detail.

And I'm not criticizing, that's just the fact.

BARTIROMO: Yes --

BARBOUR: Public use very little about the issues.

BARTIROMO: Yes, but to be fair, I mean, in our debates that we've done here at the Fox Business Network, we stuck to the issues, we got a chance to really talk about tax reform.

Did you hear anything that you feel would resonate with people, senator?

MITCHELL: Well, it's very difficult in the current campaign mode, particularly these debates.

No criticism of anybody when you got a dozen people up on the stage and you got 30 or 60 seconds to answer a question.

It's conducive to bumper stickers, slogans and superficial statements --

BARTIROMO: That's true --

BARBOUR: If you get up and make a reasonable statement, you'll never get on the television news or get in the newspapers.

Could I just add one point then, not to disagree with Haley, the feeling of dissatisfaction goes back a lot longer than two or three years.

You'll recall in 2007, 2008 and 2009, we had a very difficult economic circumstance.

We were losing 400,000 jobs a month at the -- at the bottom of the recession in which we dropped and there was enormous dissatisfaction then.

Since then, it's come back some in the President's term, 15 million new jobs have been created.

We have the strongest economy in the world by far, how it's relative and turning to -- and Russia have far more serious problems than we do.

But we still have serious issues that we have not been able to overcome, that will take a unified effort.

And one of the long term disadvantages of these polarizing campaigns is that it's hard to get people working together again after the election.

BARTIROMO: Yes --

BARBOUR: When we really need to pull together to try to solve some of the long range issues that are not attributable to one party or the other, to one president or another.

But really are attributable to underlying economic, social and cultural forces that are affecting not just the people of this country, but people all around the world.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I guess governor, as you said, people are frustrated that we're not farther along.

I mean, you're right, the financial crisis in 2008 is where this feelings started.

But they're looking in the last 7 years and saying, my wages haven't moved, my situation hasn't changed much.

BARBOUR: Well, the recovery has been the weakest since World War II about 2.2 percent a year economic growth which is about half as much growth per year as after the last deep recession in the '80s.

BARTIROMO: Right --

BARBOUR: Median household income is actually less than it was eight years ago. Those kinds of things, people notice. You know --

BARTIROMO: Right --

BARBOUR: A lot of people will say they can't tell the difference between the recession and the recovery.

BARTIROMO: Yes --

BARBOUR: And so people are down, and we need everybody to work together. George Mitchell is right about that as he's right about very many things.

BARTIROMO: Governor, thank you, senator, good to see you.

MITCHELL: Thank you, Maria --

BARTIROMO: Appreciate it very much, we'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. A mystery illness forcing American airlines flights to making emergency landing.

Breaking news now with Cheryl Casone. Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS: I tell you what, Maria, still no answers on this.

A Los Angeles-bound American Airlines flight forced to return to London's Heathrow after several people including a flight attendant fell ill.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: There was a lot of commotion and they immediately threw the lights on, and then maybe five minutes later, they announced that 7 of the 13 flight attendants on board had either passed out or were too sick to fulfill their duties.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: So, yes, one flight attendant passed out. Officials say that paramedics examined and they discharged six people who complained of feeling light-headed.

That plane had 188 people on board. They did check the air, no results yet. And check this out.

Calgary Flames defenseman Dennis Wideman checking the referee Don Henderson in what appears to be an intentional hit.

This is big. It happened after Wideman took a hit against the boards from one of the Nashville Predators.

Wideman does face possible suspension over the video that you're seeing right there.

And finally, you may want to check your credit card statement if you've eaten at Wendy's recently.

The fast-food chain launching an investigation in what it is calling unusual activity related to customers cars. Maria.

Really quick here. The banks are the ones that flagged Wendy's that they had an issue, so there's one for the banks for you, back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right, Cheryl, thank you. An earnings blowout from Facebook. Meanwhile, that has the stock of the social networking giant surging this morning more than 13 percent in the pre-market.

How a rallying today's session could push the company to see its biggest gain in nearly two years. Back in a minute with more Facebook.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. It's all about technology on the upside. Two tech heavyweights surging in the pre-market after posting strong quarterly results.

Jo Ling Kent with all the numbers and the details. Jo.

JO LING KENT, FOX BUSINESS: It's a good day if you own Facebook or Alibaba, what a morning for both of those companies.

Alibaba reporting blockbuster earnings, showing that for now their consumers continue to consume a lot in China.

They posted revenue of $5.33 billion, beating expectations for $5.03 billion. EPS also a beat at 99 cents versus 87 cents.

Alibaba says it now has 407 million annual active buyers, that's more than the population of the United States, and mobile revenue is up 192 percent year-over-year to $101 billion.

Global merchandize volume also up 23 percent year-over-year to 149 billion. And Alibaba surging on this news in the pre-market, up about 4 percent right now in the pre-market.

Another big story this morning. Facebook trading up 12 percent ahead of the bell after earnings beat on revenue and everywhere actually.

Facebook says it earned $3.73 a share for everyone of its 1.59 billion monthly active users.

And I thought this -- that was really interesting. A 100 million hours of video are watched on Facebook every single day.

And Mark Zuckerberg planning to spend big on Instagram, later being for internet access and other big ventures.

So, we can see the spending rate continue to go up for Facebook, but they've been able to match it with revenue and its mobile ad revenue.

BARTIROMO: Its mobile ad revenue, and you know, interestingly, earlier, we were talking about this, and someone said, look, it's not just about mobile.

Advertisers say, I want to be reaching clients, and the bottom-line is --

LING KENT: Target --

BARTIROMO: That's where the target declines are.

LING KENT: It really is one of the only places on social media where you can reach a very large audiences, very targeted and actually get something out of it.

And the metric that Sheryl Sandberg(ph) mentioned on the call last night, she basically said they can do it with politics and small businesses and big brands.

No one else is able to do that right now.

BARTIROMO: Yes, Dagen McDowell back on set. Some pretty big wins for these companies.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS: And this is -- this is really good news for the markets that you can have a company that really delivers, that looks good.

Anastasia was pointing to the fact that it has a very large concentration of business in the United States, which is positive.

And have a stock that it raises about a 10 percent loss so far this year, potentially in one day.

They've got a lot of upside video here, only about 20 percent so far. They've got is really monetize --

BARTIROMO: Yes --

MCDOWELL: That, Whatsapp, also, the Atlas Rift headset, that virtual reality headset is coming out which I'm pretty stoked about --

BARTIROMO: Yes --

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Yes, me too --

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Yes, I was just going to say, you know, and this is an election-year, too.

So, you know ad spending from that side is going to shoot way up and Facebook obviously is the key component.

LING KENT: They talked about that --

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Right --

LING KENT: Last night actually, and Sheryl Sanberg(ph) said it's going very well, politically.

But what they see is not just the presidential candidates revenue coming in, it's local politicians that are really using --

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Right --

LING KENT: To their --

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Yes --

LING KENT: Advantage --

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Because of the targeted nature --

BARTIROMO: I know --

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Sorry, go ahead.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: I want to comment on the Alibaba. To me, that's the other encouraging story so far this morning.

Because we all know that China has been in this transition from the -- you know, the investment-driven economy to the consumption-driven economy.

It seems like at least the consumer is actually holding up in China when the investment piece we know certainly not.

LING KENT: Yes, it seems like the psychology hasn't really affected consumption, and especially when people on Alibaba are spending very small amounts, and then some people spend more.

But they continue to get people on-boarding on mobile first.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Yes, it might be an indication that the shift from the capital intensive, you know, infrastructure to the consumer-led.

This is actually starting to work pretty well. And these are the type of companies that you want to be invested in, in China.

LING KENT: We'll see. I'm always skeptical of Alibaba and the structure of the company and the regulations and kind of fit issues. So --

BARTIROMO: Yes, you're right --

LING KENT: And that, so --

BARTIROMO: And that's a number of people were when they first went public. Jo, thanks.

LING KENT: Thanks.

BARTIROMO: Coming up next, presidential candidate Mike Huckabee will join me next to discuss his game plan for tonight's GOP debate.

Before we take a break, take a look at this. DeLorean is going back to the future and into production.

The DeLorean Motor Company is in Texas, will begin making cars after a 34- year break.

Under a new manufacturing bill, they'll build 300 replica 1982 models like that famous car in back to the future.

They start rolling off the assembly line next year, a $100,000 per vehicle, back in a minute.

(MUSIC)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Breaking news, durable goods down 5.1 percent. The number is just out a moment ago. This is not as bad as some were expecting, still looking at a decline down 5.1 percent on durable goods orders, however, not as bad as the expectations called for. It -- it -- Anastasia, how do you see this number?

ANASTASIA AMOROSO, JP MORGAN ASSET MANAGEMENT: It certainly -- the durable goods order continues to be a disappointing number. I mean, all of this is a function of three forces that are playing in the markets right now, which is low oil, high dollar.

BARTIROMO: Oh, I got to -- I got to correct myself. It's down 5.1 percent. I thought it was five tenth. Down 5.1 percent is much worse than expected, 5.1 percent.

AMOROSO: That is an incredibly bad number.

BARTIROMO: Down 5.1 percent. Wow.

ANDY BUSCH, GLOBAL MARKET STRATEGIST: What's ex -- what's external lines (ph), that's .

AMOROSO: It -- it certainly -- if that's the number, that's certainly a huge disappointment. And again, we have energy deploying for it, we probably have China to blame for it. It would be a huge mess.

BARTIROMO: It is, 5.1 percent.

BUSCH: Yeah. I think it means the fourth quarter has been --it's going to be horrendous. I mean, we already have from the Atlanta GDP now number, looking at -- at plus point 7. I think we may take that down a notch or two for -- for what GDP will be in this. Place in that team (ph) but things are bad, things are slowing down, earnings aren't there, so this is all part of that. I don't want to read too much in a volatile number, but we know that, you know, these are things that factor into how you look at whether you should be invested, how much you should be invested or not. It's just slowing earnings, slowing GDP.

BARTIROMO: I believe for a while, durable goods were down for 11 straight months. I don't think we've seen an increase. I think we're continuing on this trend of down sharply, for .

AMOROSO: Yeah.

BARTIROMO: . now almost a year.

AMOROSO: We absolutely are, and you also see that in the PMI manufacturing surveys. For example, whether you look at the new orders component, whether you .

BUSCH: Right.

AMOROSO: . look at the employment component, all of them have been declining. But this miss is a huge miss. And this really, I guess shows how much belt tightening that companies have been .

(LAUGHTER)

. doing in the fourth quarter to navigate this very challenging environment.

BUSCH: Well, it's interesting because jobless claims are 278, because that's the ying and the yang here, right. So, we got obviously -- on the one side, manufacturing, durable goods that looks really soft. And on the other side, employment is holding up really well and jobless claims I think is -- is a really good, real time number field for how the employment situation is in the United States, instead of the monthly non-comparable (ph) numbers.

So, I'd like to look at that one, especially the four-week average, and it's holding up really well. I think that's why most economist are saying, it's hard to see like a dramatic drop off in the U.S. economy or a recession in 2016 with those types of numbers.

BARTIROMO: Yeah.

AMOROSO: This is -- this is exactly why the fed had to do what they did yesterday. They have to stop and reassess the balance of risk. Because clearly, as we see today, as we've seen too Maria your point for the last year, risks are building for the manufacturing sector. Will they spill over into the service sector? So there's two key things that we will be watching in the service sector. First is the service employment. We will get that in the PMI surveys once again, even before we get into the job numbers. The second thing is consumer credit. That's why the question was asked here earlier in the show, is, once you seek consumer credit rolling over that could be a pretty strong indicator. We're not seeing that yet in the four-week ...

(CROSSTALK)

BUSCH: Yeah, because of.

AMOROSO: . average basis.

BUSCH: . the jobs are holding up, right?

AMOROSO: For now, yeah, for now, but .

BUSCH: Yeah.

BARTIROMO: Do you believe that though? I mean, that's the thing, I mean, the jobs are holding up. You -- you see more job improvement, but, you know, when you look at things like durable goods down 5.1 percent, much worse than expected. You look at what's happening in the commodities complex.

AMOROSO: Yeah.

BARTIROMO: The -- the collapse that we've seen. That's showing you a completely different economy than the job improvements.

AMOROSO: It is. You know, for now, it's all about the service jobs, because that's the biggest chunk of the economy. But I will say Maria that as the stock market is down 6 or 7 percent, and as investors have not really seen stellar returns for even the prior year. As investors look at their household net worth, it's not necessarily declining, because housing prices are still going up. But it certainly not increasing at the pace that it was increasing at before. So, that could potentially dent the confidence and perhaps further slowdown the momentum that we've already seen .

BARTIROMO: Yeah.

AMOROSO: . slowdown in the fourth.

BUSCH: Well, and a lot of consumers too, and this could be happening as well. They've never experienced like having money and a job in -- in its (ph) normal recession. They've only experienced the great recession, right. And so they think that when the economy slows, holy cow, the world is going to fall apart. It's not necessarily going to happen, but it will feel like because that's your only frame of reference. So, I think it's a great point to watch consumer spending for sure, of course, but let's see if that psychology continues to play through.

BARTIROMO: Yes, it's a good point that there are stages set, of course, for the Fox News Republican presidential debate, meanwhile. Candidates are hoping to make a lasting impression on Iowa voters before they cast their votes on Monday. Joining us right now is Republican presidential candidate, Mike Huckabee, Governor, good to see you. Thank you so much for joining us.

MIKE HUCKABEE, PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: Thank you, Maria, great to be here. It's cold out here.

BARTIROMO: Yeah, it's cold in Iowa, we know. We're just getting the numbers for durable goods order and its cold there as well, by the way. Because you got an economy that continues to shows signs of deteriorating. Are you hearing these concerns from Iowa voters right now, governor?

HUCKABEE: Absolutely, Maria. You know, when I heard the president in his state of the union trying to talk about how great the economy is doing, he's just missing it. He needs to get out more. And if he would come here in Iowa, he would talk to single moms like the one I spoke to the other night in Indianola. They'll talk about how difficult it is for her, how she's trying to go to work, but if she does, she loses all the benefits, her kids basically ends up in dire poverty. Are the man who makes $59 thousand a year in Davenport, Iowa. He told me that on $59 thousand a year, he and his wife, that's all on their insurance. Obamacare this year it's going to cost them $28 thousand, that's half their income. These are the stories of real Americans

BARTIROMO: I Agree.

HUCKABEE: These are the people that have lost their jobs.

BUSCH: And governor, Andy Busch here, I think what's interesting on the Republican side, and your certainly part of this, I haven't seen this in a very, very long time. Where the Republican candidate have put out detailed tax plan, and I think yours it's very interesting, because it's a national sales tax. But you eliminate the income tax and you also have full expensing but contained -- walk us through why that is important for Iowa.

HUCKABEE: Well, it's important for all of America. Because right now we tax capital and labor, so everything we make in America has 22 percent embedded tax in it. But they're not taxing capital and labor in competing countries like Mexico, China, Indonesia. As a result of that, we're getting hammered. People are losing manufacturing job, 5 million since the year 2000. Trillions of dollars of money is parked offshore. That would be in our economy but it isn't, because people are protecting it from the income tax. So if we stop punishing, which means taxing the productivity of workers, if we stop taxing the investment of investors, then we have work and investment coming back. We're losing both. And that's why the fair tax is a superior alternative to taxing people productivity, their income, their investment.

BARTIROMO: Why do you think you will be able to get tax reform through when we have been talking about this for so many years, and it's so impossible to get done?

HUCKABEE: You have to have leadership to do it. It's never going to get done without a president who can explain it, who can articulate it, and who can make Americans understand how this helps them. And that's one of the reasons that I am in this race. Because I don't think most of the tax plans -- I hear some of these guys and all they're doing is tap in the hammer, twisting the screwdriver. It's tinkering with the tax code. But the power of the tax code is the power to shake down the donors, so that they can get contributions to the political campaigns. They get tax breaks to the people who give them donors. And look, the people who are taking the gut punches are the folks out here in Middle America, who don't make millions of dollars a year. They're hoping to hold on to a $45-$50 thousand a year income, if that. They're the ones are whom tax reform makes a world of difference and puts them back in the game of being in the middle class.

BARTIROMO: So, how do you prepare for tonight, governor? How do you think tonight will be different given the fact that Donald Trump will not be on the stage, and what are you doing to sort of breakout?

HUCKABEE: Well, you know, I got to just answer the questions honestly. I hope we have sensitive questions we have in the last few debates, and I think that's been very helpful. Quite frankly, I'm not just now kissing up to you guys, but the Fox Business debates, the two most substance debate that we have had in the entire cycle, and I say that sincerely.

BARTIROMO: Thank you very much, sir. We appreciate that.

HUCKABEE: Because the questions are about issues. They're truly were. They're really genuinely worth. And that's what we need tonight. We need questions that focus on the people of America, and what we would do as president to help their lives get back on track so that we can hand this country to our kids and grandkids in better shape that we are finding it right now.

BARTIROMO: And you think it's going to be a real, sort of, different, a stark difference with Donald Trump not on stage?

HUCABEE: You know, I don't know, I want to be on stage with him. I think, way too many people are talking about Donald Trump, and they're not talking about these Americans out there, you know, who lost their jobs at the Newton, Iowa, Maytag plant when it shut down. And you know, it's not about Donald Trump. It's not about me. It's not about any of the other candidates. It really oath to be about how Americans are getting hammered out there every single day, and you watch people and you look at the -- just their faces and you see their sense of frustration, you see their anger. It's like they know that the people who are showing out the big bucks to the politician, they're fine, they're going to be great. They're not going to have to miss a vacation. They'll jet away to the Caribbean when it's cold. And they'll summer in the Hamptons and go to Maine. But these folks aren't even able to, you know, 50 miles from home and have a vacation. And they just want to know that somebody is going to be out there fighting for them. That's why I hope the debate can be about.

BARTIROMO: I would love to run a little bit of your ad, governor. The Adele song, do we have that? Here it comes.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: OK, governor, what were you thinking with this?

HUCKABEE: Well, it was my inner Adele. I think sometimes we have to Back up and have some fun with this stuff. And one of the things we wanted to do is to show that as we travel out there around Iowa, on the frozen tundra, of snow covered cornfields, you know, there are people in all these cities, and we try to bring a little culture of Iowa, do it in a fun way. Interesting is the reaction has gone to some people said, that's the funniest thing we've seen this cycle, others say that's the dumbest, most cringed worthy, corniest, nonsense we ever seen in our lives. So, the good news is, everybody is talking about it.

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: We like her beautiful voice. Governor, good to see you, thanks so much you're a sport for explaining it, thanks very much.

HUCKABEE: You bet.

BARTIRMO: We'll see you soon. Good luck in Iowa, Mike Huckabee, joining us right there.

HUCKABEE: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Take a short break. And we got more coverage of what is much worse than expected durable goods report, down 5.1 percent. More Mornings With Maria, straight ahead.

JESSICA VILCHIS, TENNIS CHANNEL REPORTER: Welcome back to another Tennis Channel court report, a special presentation for Fox Business, I'm Jessica Vilchis. At 34, Serena Williams is already the oldest woman to win a major. But at this stage of her career, the world's number one is all about the history books and for tennis legacy. Williams blasted Agnieszka Radwanska off the court in their semifinal in Melbourne, giving Serena a shot at winning her 22nd major title, and to tie Steffi Graf in the all- time list. The American fired 8 aces and 42 winners in comprehensive straight set win. She'll Play Angelique Kerber for the title after the German took care of business against Great Britain, Johanna Konta. Kerber has Beaten Williams just once in six previous meetings, with that victory coming back in 2012. And don't forget Tennis Channel live coverage from Melbourne, continues Thursday at 10 PM Eastern.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIRMO: With that massive weekend snowstorm hitting drivers in the nation's capital where it hurts, their wallets. Cheryl Casone with that and the other headlines right now, Cheryl

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK: Oh yeah, Maria. Washington, D.C. handing out tickets totaling more than $1 million for violators of its parking ban since in-acting as snow emergencies last Friday. The city has issued more than 5200 snow emergency tickets, each at a cost of $250. A woman mammoth remains discovered during construction at Oregon State University. The school said the crews recovered a large bone on Monday, for the digging revealed more bones from several extinct mammals. Santa Claus under arrest, this guy whose legal name really is Santa Claus was charged driving under the influence, after Idaho police said they saw him driving on the wrong side of the street. And finally, Maria, and ladies, this is amazing. Barbie is getting a whole new body. The so-called the world's bestselling doll is actually getting three new bodies. They're going to have petite, tall, and my favorite is going to be curvy. Pastel and Mattel still plan to make the original fit of waist of Barbie, but in the age of Beyonce and Kim Kardashian, great message going out to kids everywhere, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Trying to be more realistic, I guess.

CASONE: Yeah, it should be.

BARTIROMO: Thank you, Cheryl. I like that. Still to come, amazing numbers from China E-commerce Alibaba, stocks getting it boast from the pre-markets, and then there's Facebook. Plus, an incredible cloud formation over Portugal, captured in film. Take a look at this photo. Some saying it looks more like the hand of God holding a fireball than clouds.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK: Good morning, I'm Nicole Petallides, live on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange. U.S. stock futures are looking to the upside, about 47 point on the Dow Jones Industrial average right now, S&P futures up about 8. We're looking for some movers today, you have Deutsche Bank pulling back. Semis could lead the way, names like United Micro, Terradigm, Texas Instrument. Alibaba and Facebook, two names we know so well. Alibaba came out with sales expectations that wowed Wall Street, in fact, profit more than double, and also, saying their well position for China's Shift to consumption and services going forward. That stock is likely to be a big winner here up about 6 percent. Facebook shares also soaring in the pre-market, up more than 10 percent throughout this morning. Mobile moves, obviously that has been the big story there. And Mark Zuckerberg now moves to the sixth richest man in the world. More Mornings With Maria, coming up.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. I am with Anastasia Amoroso, from JP Morgan, and Andy Busch this morning. Let's talk about the durable goods report you guys, much worse than expected, Anastasia, December durable goods missing expectations by a wide margin, down 5.1 percent.

AMOROSO: Yes, Maria. Frankly, when you first of that number, I couldn't believe it, because it's such a big miss. Digging through the numbers we have to take out the very volatile defense component, and the very volatile transportation component. So, for example defense orders were down about 34 percent. And non-defense aircraft orders were down about 30 percent. So, that's what driven a lot of those numbers. But, even when I take transportation out of the equation, you are still looking at durable goods being down, 1.2 percent, once again missing expectation. As Andy and I, was just talking about, not only that we miss these expectations, we also saw downward revisions to the November numbers. Look, it's undeniable that the state of the manufacturing sector in the United States and globally is in recession.

BARTIROMO: Look, and this tells you that businesses are holding back, on spending, their holding back on putting money into plants and equipment's, Andy.

BUSCH: Yeah. And I think, well, look at durable goods, the disappointing component of it is the fact that consumer spending is not holding up. You would have thought with the lower gas lean, you start be a dust, start to see a pick up there. But, I think, also, it underscores, you know, as far as growth goes, we need to do something fundamentally globally that to change the picture. It isn't quantitative easing anymore, it isn't monetary easing, this really has to get it. Economic reform in the United States, it's really tax reform. One thing I just want to point out, I mean, I wrote two articles going through Cruz, Rubio, and Trump, plans, but I just want to point out is that they have full expensing. What does that mean? It means companies can write off plants and equipment's in the year that they do it. That would generate huge economic growth in the United States. But don't believe me, you can go to a tax foundation and take a look at it. But, it is really important and I believe it will happen.

BARTIROMO: Well, that's an interesting point. Because this is exactly what this report speaks to. They're not spending money on plants and equipment. You're saying, if in fact we were to see tax reform, because up until now it has been all about the Fed. We know that, monetary policy. We need some fiscal policy. If we were to see tax they can get a break, tax wise on investing plants and equipment.

BUSCH: Well you can write off wages in the year that you have and expense for business. But, you can't do that with a plant. You have to re-shade it 10, 20, 30 years, it's ridiculous. It should be in the year that you make the payment, right? And that's what I think. Hold back to the United States, all of these, you know, these questions about offshoring and plants overseas, big tech, big pharma, you cut their tax rate, they will bring this money back. That's the international component tax reform. But the full expensing will really drive it higher, and I am excited about that. But we need to get going on it.

BARTIROMO: So, you analyze Cruz's plan, Rubio

BUSCH: Yes, Cruz, Trump, and Rubio.

BARTIROMO: OK. I want to hear your thoughts next time on Carson's plan, because he's really getting really high marks on his tax plan. Anastasia, let me ask you this, we're already in recession when you look at the industrial side of the economy. Does this mean, that this durable goods number, does this make you feel like we could go into an out now recession in '16?

AMOROSO: I don't think so. I think the consumer can slow is the function of the stock markets. Then I'll tell you what I'm most worried about, real quick, it's China. You know, China is fighting a wild battle, whether it comes to the stock market, to their property market, credit market, the Yuan, and of course, the economy can't solve them all at once, the answer is probably not. So, Andy's point is exactly right, we need a new fiscal policy that would be a stimulus, because China was a huge global stimulus before. It's not anymore.

BARTIRMO: Yeah, and that's why you're saying exports down, you're seeing the manufacturing are down, it does have a lot to do with China.

AMOROSO: Yes it does.

BARTIROMO: Then what do you think this rally all about? Up 85 points on the Dow Jones Industrial Average, this is just happening in the last half an hour, do you think it's because people are saying, look, Federal Reserve never going to be able to raise rates in March.

AMOROSO: I think that is exactly right. I think they're delaying the rating increases. I think it's Mario Draghi doing more of the OJ, doing more of that what's about. How long can it go on, I don't know?

BARTIROMO: Andy Busch, engaged communications, good to see you.

BUSCH: My pleasure.

BARTIROMO: Come back soon my friend.

BUSCH: You bet.

BARTIROMO: Anastasia Amoroso, always a pleasure.

AMOROSO: Great to see you.

BARTIROMO: Will see you soon, from JP Morgan. That will do it for us, Varney and Co. up next, Stuart, over to you, take it away.

END

urn:contentItem:5J0S-DBK1-DY0W-43NC-00000-00Republican Candidates Gear Up for Fox News Debate in Iowa; U.S. Futures Point to Gains; Facebook Stock Skyrockets as Mobile Drives Big Jump;[1]2016-01-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:21:31ZLexisNexisRepublican Candidates Gear Up for Fox News Debate in Iowa; U.S. Futures Point to Gains; Facebook Stock Skyrockets as Mobile Drives Big Jump[1]LanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, HOST, MORNINGS WITH MARIA: Good morning everybody, I'm Maria Bartiromo.

Welcome back, the top stories on this Thursday, January 28th at 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Republican candidates gearing up for tonight's debate in Iowa. The event hosted by our sister network, the Fox News channel.

It's the final GOP debate before the Iowa caucuses this upcoming Monday. Frontrunner, Donald Trump says he still won't participate in tonight's event.

He went on the "O'REILLY FACTOR" last night to explain his decision.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BILL O'REILLY, FOX NEWS: I --

DONALD TRUMP, CHAIRMAN & PRESIDENT, TRUMP ORGANIZATIONS & FOUNDER, TRUMP ENTERTAINMENT RESORTS: Right --

O'REILLY: Submit to you that you need to change and get away from the personal -- they hurt my feelings, are unfair to me.

And they get about them, the folks, not about you. And you elevate them to a place where you could win this if you do that. Am I crazy?

TRUMP: You're not crazy at all, but it is about them, it's about making America great again.

That's why I'm doing this. It's not because I want the position, it's because I know the potential of this country, how great the country can be.

Our leader is not doing the job.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Be sure to tune in tonight for the Fox News-Google debate, beginning at 7:00 p.m. Eastern on the Fox News channel.

Let's look at markets right here. Futures pointing to modest gains at the opening of trading.

Take a look, we've been back and forth between positive and negative territories this morning, we are expecting a higher opening for the Dow about 40 points high.

Nasdaq looking good, up 33 points, of course the Federal Reserve yesterday raised questions about the next time it will be able to raise interest rates.

Same with the economy did in fact slowdown at the end of last year. In Europe, markets are lower this morning across the board.

Take a look, down between two-thirds of 1 percent and one and a third percent. The Dax index in Germany down.

Hundred and thirty five points right now, that's the low of the morning, down better than 1 percent. And in Asia overnight, tough night in China.

The Shanghai composite down nearly 3 percent on the session, that set the tone. The Nikkei average down three-quarters of 1 percent.

Facebook, the stock to watch today. The social media giant handily beating earnings expectations.

Revenue soared better than 50 percent in the fourth quarter from a year earlier, driven by mobile advertising.

The stock jumping in the pre-market this morning, Facebook up sharply right now. Growing concern this morning about the Zika virus.

The United Nations is holding an emergency meeting on Monday to determine whether the virus should be deemed an international health emergency.

This as new cases of the Zika virus confirmed in the United States just this morning. There are now at least six cases including New York.

Republican presidential candidates getting ready to face off tonight in the Fox News debate in Iowa.

The last GOP debate before Monday's Iowa caucuses. Blake Burman is in Des Moines right now with the preview of what to expect tonight. Blake.

BLAKE BURMAN, FOX BUSINESS: Hi there, Maria, good morning to you. Donald Trump continues to maintain steadfastly that he will not be here at the Fox News debate tonight, later tonight here in Des Moines.

This is still an incredibly important debate for so many different reasons. Not only is it the final debate in the lead up until the Iowa caucuses on Monday night.

But also the first debate here in Iowa as well, over the issues for Iowa voters will be front and center.

There will be 11 other candidates here guaranteed later tonight. The 9:00 debate has seven candidates on that stage.

Cruz and Rubio will be front and center, they'll be flanked by Carson and Bush, Christie and Kasich, and Rand Paul makes his return to the 9:00 debate stage.

But this all kicks off at 7:00 with four candidates: Fiorina, Huckabee and Santorum. Jim Gilmore also returns to this debate.

I was speaking with an adviser yesterday of Ted Cruz, and that adviser told me that his campaign feels that Cruz will be the one receiving the cross- fire now.

Because if Trump isn't there, they say, you know what? People shoot up in these debates, Cruz is running second in the polls, they expect their guy to get a lot of the heat tonight.

Still, they told me, Maria, Donald Trump will not going to pass.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. TED CRUZ (R), TEXAS: But at the end of the day, it's not really the Donald who is afraid of Megyn.

It's not that he's afraid of Mark or Sean or Rush. It's not that he's afraid of me. He's afraid of you.

He doesn't want to answer questions from the men and women of Iowa about how his record doesn't match what he's selling.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: Things still look good for Trump here. A new "Wall Street Journal" poll out this morning shows he has 32 percent support from Iowa caucus, though rose at 7 points ahead of Cruz, Rubio comes in at 18 as well.

That poll also shows in the other early states of New Hampshire and South Carolina that Trump lead big. Maria, back to to you.

BARTIROMO: All right, Blake, thanks so much Blake Burman. And joining us right now is former Senate Majority leader George Mitchell and former RNC chairman and former Mississippi Governor Haley Barbour.

Good to see you both gentlemen, thanks so much for joining us.

GEORGE MITCHELL, FORMER SENATE MAJORITY LEADER: Thank you, Maria --

BARTIROMO: Senator, let me kick this off with you. What's your take on what's going on right now?

Is Trump not showing up tonight, is that going to be good for him or do you think he loses in this?

MITCHELL: I think it's probably not good for him, the more important question is, will it derail his efforts in it, I doubt that.

BARTIROMO: So, it won't be good for him, but it won't derail him either?

MITCHELL: No, I don't think it would. Ted Cruz himself said, I think it was yesterday that, if Trump wins Iowa and then goes on to win New Hampshire which proves likely, he'll be unstoppable.

And on that I think Senator Cruz may be right.

BARTIROMO: Wow, governor, what do you think?

HALEY BARBOUR, FORMER MISSISSIPPI GOVERNOR: Well, obviously, Trump thinks it's good for him or he wouldn't be doing it.

This is -- I don't think this is about his feelings being hurt. I think he made the calculation he's got more to lose by being in the debate than not being in the debate.

But we'll see. He's -- if the polling is to be believed, he's got a solid lead in both of these states.

I don't think anybody has got it in the bag. I don't think the idea that somebody is inevitable if they win both these debates is accurate, but I guess, he gets a mighty powerful momentum --

BARTIROMO: Yes --

BARBOUR: If he wins both of them.

BARTIROMO: I think this is a really good point. But let me ask you about what he said about you governor, because he was asked about you with George Stephanopoulos.

And he said, look, Haley Barbour, he's an old-time politician, he's been up in my office looking for money many times, Trump says.

He's an old-time politician who is losing his grip. Frankly, I haven't heard the name Haley Barbour ever mentioned in a year and a half, and the reason that me and Ted Cruz are in the lead is because of that.

What do you think about this governor?

BARBOUR: Well, he's certainly right that I'm old. But the fact is, George Stephanopoulos, the next day apologized for telling Donald Trump that I had said something about him that I didn't say.

In fact, I hadn't said anything about him. I've only met the guy twice in my life and one time he took me to a heavyweight championship fight in Atlantic City when I was RNC chairman back in the -- back in the '90s.

I've stayed out of this just like I did in 2008 and 2012 as a former national party chairman.

That's what I have intended to do and I've done it again. I'm going to support the nominee of the party, because I don't think our country can stay four more years with Obama's policies.

And that's what we'll get if we elect Hillary Clinton or Bernie Sanders. But that's what I'm going to do.

I'm going to follow Reagan's 11th commandment, I was a political director to (INAUDIBLE) and Ronald Reagan, that's what he preached and practiced.

And that's what I start to practice --

BARTIROMO: Yes, you're right. Stephanopoulos apologized because basically he was starting this thing between the two of you, and you didn't even say anything.

It was actually --

BARBOUR: That is right --

BARTIROMO: Henry Barbour, the former -- your nephew and --

BARBOUR: That's exactly right --

BARTIROMO: A Republican strategist, so he said it, he brings up your name as if you said it, and Trump lashes at you for no reason.

But Senator Mitchell --

BARBOUR: OK --

BARTIROMO: The idea that Bernie Sanders is in the lead in Iowa on the Dem side and Trump is in the lead on the Republican side.

What does it say about our country right now?

MITCHELL: Well, I think there's a lot of frustration, anger, that happens whenever the economy turns down.

The President who campaigns provide an outlet for frustration that people feel. Particularly those who aren't moving up in the new economy.

We figured out a way to encourage innovation, we have the technological revolutions which we're now passing.

We'll be seeing in the future as important in human affairs as it was the industrial revolution.

But we haven't figured out how to replace the jobs that had been lost. What I call the working man middle income jobs.

Factory worker who could support a wife and two children. And that frustration will continue for a long time and it's finding its expression now in the presidential campaign on both sides.

But I think you're going to see a closely contested election in the general election. The country is pretty much divided.

The parties, well, I think generally unite, you heard Hillary say he'll support whoever the nominee is.

BARTIROMO: Right --

MITCHELL: And an interesting way, Trump is the nominee will help the Democrats unite and Secretary Clinton as the Democratic nominee will help the Republicans unite.

So, although, history isn't much of a guide in this election, history tells us that you can have a hotly contested nominee processes and still find the parties coming together.

BARTIROMO: Are you surprised Bernie Sanders is beating Hillary in Iowa?

MITCHELL: No, I think that he's beating Hillary in the polls, and as you see from the poll results, it's overwhelmingly among young people.

The question still is whether they will turn out to vote. But I think once you get past New Hampshire, he isn't in his favorable territory as he is in these first two states.

BARTIROMO: Governor, what about you? You know, you've been the chairman of the RNC, what do you think in terms of how this plays out next several months?

How important is Iowa followed by New Hampshire? What are the other states that you think will really give us a sense of who in fact people are voting for?

BARBOUR: Well, when you go down to the south, you'll see if you get different results, but I'm not sure that you will.

But I think George Mitchell makes very important points. The country is very evenly divided.

But there's so much polarity. There's so much division and it is because as he said, people in our country are dissatisfied.
